entry.title: Streamlining Access Policies in SAP Cloud Integration(CI/CPI) for Multi-Team Tenant
entry.content:
Access policies within SAP Cloud Integration (CI/CPI) are crucial for managing and organizing resources effectively when multiple teams are working within the same tenant. While there is an excellent blog available which covers the basics on access policies (blog), this blog aims to address the unique challenges that arise when multiple teams need tailored access and wish to avoid clutter caused by unnecessary package creation.

Understanding the Requirements:

If your tenant is bustling with unwanted or empty packages, think names like "PoC Package" or "Test123"—then it’s likely time to optimize your access policies. This blog offers practical solutions for the following requirements:

  1. Dedicated Access for Teams: Ensure that different teams within your organization do not have unauthorized access to each other’s integration packages.
  2. Targeted Permissions: Assign package access exclusively to the designated teams.
  3. Artifact Creation Control: Prevent teams from creating integration artifacts like iFlows, Value Mappings, and Message Mappings in unassigned packages.
  4. Prevent Package Clutter: Implement a strategy to avoid the creation of unnecessary packages within the tenant.

Example Scenario:

Consider three teams: Team 1, Team 2, and Team 3.

Two users are part of this setup—User 1 belongs to Team 1, and User 2  belongs to Team 2.

Users should have access to packages as depicted below.

For Requirements #1 and #2:

User 1 should have access to Team 1 Package and Housekeeping Package. Here’s how:

Create a new role within Access Policy

Assign the required packages.

Define a custom role in BTP Cockpit.

Associate this role with a custom Role Collection.

Link this Role Collection to User 1.

 

User 2 is to be granted Team 2 Package access following similar steps.

Create a new role within Access Policy

Assign the required packages.

Define a custom role in BTP Cockpit.

Associate this role with a custom Role Collection.

Link this Role Collection to User 1.

Testing User Access:

User 1: Can edit and incorporate integration artifacts within the Housekeeping Package and Team 1 Package, but not Team 2 Package.

User 2: Can modify and add integration artifacts in Team 2 Package but lacks the same permissions for Team 1 Package.

For more, please refer here

 

Kindly Note:

Both User 1 and User 2 can edit Team 3 Package and create integration artifacts which should not be the case as per our requirement #3

Solution for Requirement #3:

To prevent integration artifact creation in unassigned packages, create a new role in Access Policy that permits artifact creation. Importantly, do NOT assign this role or its collection to User 1 and User 2. Consequently, neither user will be able to create integration artifacts in unauthorized packages.

More Integration Artifacts can be added to this list.

Whenever user tries to access Integration Suite, following is checked in sequence.

1. Whether standard Role Collection is assigned to view the artifact

2. Whether Access Policy is applied on the content accessed

3. Whether User is provided access in Access Policy to edit the content

Now, User 1 and 2 can create integration artifacts only in their assigned packages and they can't create integration artifacts in any other packages.

Handling Unnecessary Package Creation:

User 1 & 2 can still create new packages but because of Solution #3 they cannot create any integration artifacts inside them, thereby minimizing clutter. Now, lets check how to automatically remove these empty packages from the tenant.

Solution Overview:

I have created an iFlow which connects to Integration Content APIs to detect empty packages without integration artifacts and automatically delete them.

iFlow Design :

For Integration Content API Reference, please refer this link

Following steps involved in this iflow:

1. Call GetAccess Token : This will call the Local Integration Process : Get Access Token (1)

2. In Get Access Token, we are calling the token URL from Service key of SAP Process Integration Runtime service which has api plan

3. captureAccessToken - Groovy Script: we parse json response, capture the access token and set it to a access token property

import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message
import groovy.json.JsonSlurper

def Message processData(Message message) {
    // Step 1: Get the JSON string from the message body
    def body = message.getBody(String)
    
    // Step 2: Parse the JSON input using JsonSlurper
    def jsonSlurper = new JsonSlurper()
    def jsonObject = jsonSlurper.parseText(body)
    
    // Step 3: Capture the access_token value
    def accessToken = jsonObject.access_token
    
    // Step 4: Set this value to the property accessToken
    message.setProperty("accessToken", accessToken)
    
    // Return the modified message
    return message
}

4. Set Authorization Header - Content Modifier: We set Accept and Authorization Headers

5. Request Reply : To call the API and get the list of all the Integration Packages in the tenant

 

6. JSON to XML Converter : This is used to convert JSON to XML structure

7. General Splitter - Since the response contains all the packages in a single response, we can split it based on the XPATH //results

8. Call - Empty Package Check : To call the Local Integration Process- Empty Package Check(2)

9. Set Package id - Content Modifier : to set the packageid property

 

10. Request - Reply : To check if Integration Design Time Artifacts are available inside each package

11. Call - Delete Empty Packages: To call the Local Integration Process Delete Empty Packages(3)

12. deleteEmptyPackages - Groovy Script: To parse the response and check if the response is empty (which indicates Package is empty), set the property deletePackage as true. If not, set it as false

import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message
import groovy.json.JsonSlurper

def Message processData(Message message) {
    // Retrieve the body of the message
    String body = message.getBody(String)
    
    // Parse the JSON input using JsonSlurper
    def jsonSlurper = new JsonSlurper()
    def jsonObject = jsonSlurper.parseText(body)
    
    // Check if the JSON structure matches {"d":{"results":[]}}
    def isEmptyResults = jsonObject?.d?.results?.isEmpty()
    
    // Set the property deletePackage based on the check
    if (isEmptyResults) {
        message.setProperty("deletePackage", true)
    } else {
        message.setProperty("deletePackage", false)
    }

    // Return the modified message
    return message
}

13. Router: To route the messages based on the deletePackage value

14. Request - Reply: To call the API for Package deletion

15. Exception Handling: If the package is locked then the message fails. Hence, setting a custom header with likely cause. This can be extended as per your requirement.

Testing:

Empty packages are created by User 1 & 2 because they can't create Integration Artifacts inside it because of Solution#3

Run the flow

All the empty packages are deleted now

Now, if one of the empty package is locked under a user then the flow will fail and likely cause is set as custom header which is set in exception subprocess 

Conclusion:

Efficient management of access policies within SAP Cloud Integration is essential for organizations utilizing shared environments among multiple teams. By implementing tailored access controls, you can ensure that each team has exclusive access to their designated packages. This approach optimizes collaborative workflows by preventing unauthorized modifications to integration packages.
Furthermore,  restriction on the creation of integration artifacts in unassigned packages helps in maintaining a structured and clutter-free tenant. Introducing automated solutions, like the iFlow for detecting and deleting empty packages, further streamlines operations by eliminating unnecessary resource allocation.

I invite you to share your thoughts in the comments below. Whether you have questions about Access Policies, experiences to share, or suggestions for improvement, your feedback is invaluable. It helps others who are navigating similar journeys and contributes to a community of shared knowledge. I look forward to hearing from you!

entry.title: SAP IBP new Integration Option : Introducing SAP Cloud Integration from BTP's Integration Suite
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,

 

Recently, changes in the integration layer for SAP Integrated Business Planning (IBP) were announced as you can read in the following blog entry : Enhancing SAP IBP integration - Evolution and Innovation or see in the latest IBP What’s New webinar for 2508 with regards to Integration.

📣 ⚠️ Key message ⚠️📣

While SAP Cloud Integration for Data Services (CI-DS) will remain the main ETL solution for a 1000+ existing IBP customers, especially when it comes to integrating time series data, innovations in the IBP model structure (The new harmonized planning area allowing to support both time series and order based planning) have led us to rethink and improve the integration layer for a more scalable and efficient offering.

Rest assured: there is currently no plan to sunset CI-DS, it will continue to be supported by SAP in the future.

For new IBP customers post release 2508, we encourage making use of the new harmonized planning area (sample PA called SAPIBP2) whose main integration method is SAP Real Time Integration (RTI) for master data as well as orders & stock. Anything else, especially time series data, can be covered with SAP Cloud Integration (CI)—part of SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) Integration Suite.

So what is SAP CI and how can we use it to integrate data between SAP IBP and SAP S/4HANA (private cloud / on premise) ?

This is what we will cover in this blog series.

 

Overview: What is SAP Cloud Integration?

SAP Cloud Integration is the central, cloud‑native iPaaS offering within SAP Integration Suite, enabling seamless connection of cloud and on‑premise applications, both SAP and non‑SAP.

Core capabilities include:

  • Integration flow design & monitoring via web‑based tooling,
  • Support for synchronous and asynchronous patterns, event‑based, batch, messaging, content‑based routing, IDoc/RFC flows,
  • Built‑in security, governance, and stateful processing with error handling and restart capabilities.

 

Key Capabilities & Integration Patterns

  • Prepacked integration content, accelerators and templates supported,
  • Full lifecycle support: orchestration, transformation, routing, monitoring,
  • Protocol & messaging flexibility: HTTP/HTTPS, SOAP, REST/OData, RFC/IDoc, SFTP, JMS, AS2, mail, LDAP, JDBC, plus a custom Adapter SDK,
  • Custom adapter framework: build your own adapters to any protocol or legacy system.

 

Integration Options: Adapters, APIs, Open Connectors

  • SAP‑standard adapters: e.g. SuccessFactors, Ariba, S/4HANA, Concur, SAP CRM, SAP Cloud for Customer (C4C) and now IBP,
  • Open Connectors: simplified connectivity to third‑party SaaS such as Salesforce, AWS, Dynamics CRM,
  • APIs / web services: support for REST/OData or SOAP interfaces,
  • File‑based and database integration: via SFTP, JDBC adapters,
  • Messaging-based integration: JMS, AS2 to handle enterprise messaging.

 

Let’s now focus on the initial configuration needed in the various systems to secure this IBP to S/4HANA (private/on prem) integration via CI. 

 

Initial Setup in BTP

To be able to use CI for integration purposes with IBP, you first need the following:

  • A license to SAP BTP (Purchase at SAP Store),
  • A global account must have been setup for your company, check with your IT team as it is possible you already have one for other purposes if you have a BTP license. In that case, you can use the same.
  • You need to create a BTP subaccount to consume the Integration Suite service via your BTP global account administrator.
    • Make sure Cloud Foundry Environment is enabled for your subaccount
    • Note that Integration Suite service runs only on the SAP BTP, Cloud Foundry environment.
    • To consume this application, you need to create a subscription to the Integration Suite. In the navigation bar of the SAP BTP cockpit, select Services→Service Marketplace. All resources your subaccount is entitled to consume are shown as tiles. 
    • Click on ... (Create) in the top-right corner of the Integration Suite tile. An intuitive wizard opens to guide you in a step-by-step procedure.
    • Check your subscription from your subaccount via the Services→Instances and Subscriptions section

 

  • Now, to provision the Cloud Integration tenant from the Integration Suite in the next steps, you need to add additional role.
    • User Name which should be the email address,
    • Identity Provider choose for example Default Identity Provider,
    • Email.
    • In the Security→Users section of BTP cockpit, select Create
    • Fill in the following on the new user dialog:
    • Choose Assign Role Collection and select “Integration_Provisioner”,

 

  • You can access your Integration Suite subscription as shown below with the above credentials.

 

 

 Initial Setup in Integration Suite

Now that you can access the Integration Suite application, you need to activate its capabilities to provision the Cloud Integration tenant.

  • From the Integration Suite, choose Home from the left side navigation bar.
  • Click on Add Capabilities (or Manage Capabilities if this step was already executed for other purposes),
  • In the first step of the new dialog, select Build Integration Scenarios and choose Next,

 

  • In the second step, select your environment between Production and Non Production and choose Next,
  • Finally in the third step, choose Activate.

 

Once the activation is finished, you should be able to see the added features from the newly provisioned CI tenant on the navigation bar to the left:

 

 

Initial Setup in IBP 

Now you can lay the groundwork on the IBP application side by setting up your communication arrangement based on the communication scenario "Planning – Integration Suite – Cloud Integration Integration (SAP_COM_0931)".

First, create your Communication User that will be called during the integration. Use the Maintain Communication Users application for this purpose.

  • On the Maintain Communication Users screen, choose New.
  • On the Create Communication User screen, enter the following data:
    • username,
    • description,
    • password (this will be used in the BTP application to conclude the setup).
      • Alternatively, you can create a certificate-based authentication method.

Note: above names are set as examples only.

  • Click on create.

Next, access the Communication System application to define IBP as the partner for inbound communication from CI.

  • On the Communication Systems screen, choose New.
  • In the New Communication System dialog box, enter the following data:
    • System ID,
    • System Name.
  • Click on Create from said dialog box
  • On the Communication System screen, enter the following data:
    • Select the checkbox for Inbound Only,
    • Add the communication user created in the previous step : User Name/Client ID,

 

Note: above names are set as examples only.

  • Click on Save.

 

Finally, access the Communication Arrangement application to expose inbound and outbound services that enable the communication between IBP and CI.

  • On the Communication Arrangement screen, choose New.
  • In the New Communication Arrangement dialog box, enter the following data:
    • Scenario,
    • Arrangement Name.
  • Click on Create from said dialog box
  • On the Communication Arrangement screen, enter the following data:
    • Select the communication system created in the previous step : Communication System.

 

Note: above names are set as examples only.

  • Click on Save.

The configuration for integration on the IBP side is finished.

 

Next blog entries will cover the following:

  • start working in the Integration Suite by defining destinations representing the systems (IBP and S/4HANA) the integration flows (i-flows) will connect to via RFC connections.
  • start configuring i-flows, leveraging standard prebuilt CI packages and the ERP (or S/4HANA) integration addon for SAP IBP as a starting point.

 

Sources 

  • Overview of SAP Integration Suite and SAP Cloud Integration
  • Additional information on Integrating capabilities in Integration Suite

entry.title: CPI Integration with BW/4HANA
entry.content:
Introduction

The below blog provides an overview of setting up a simple CPI integration to post data to a SAP BW/4HANA on-premise instance.  I have included an explanation of how to achieve this in both postman and SAP Cloud Integration.  I have also included references to helpful blogs you can refer to for additional details.

Set up in BW

Create DSO in BW

Ensure 'Write Interface Enabled' attribute is set.

Add fields to DSO

 

Download URL's shown on DSO

Get Structure

https://server:port/sap/bw4/v1/push/dataStores/da_maze

Get Sample Data

https://server:port/sap/bw4/v1/push/dataStores/da_maze/sampleData{?records,seed}

Send Data

https://server:port/sap/bw4/v1/push/dataStores/da_maze/dataSend{?request,datapid}

Open Request

https://server:port/sap/bw4/v1/push/dataStores/da_maze/requests

Close Request

https://server:port/sap/bw4/v1/push/dataStores/da_maze/requests/{request}/close{?error}

 

Using DSO in Postman

For Info can query DSO structure

Or see an example json payload

 

Post data in postman:

Step 1: Fetch CSRF token

Add header for x-csrf-token = fetch, set Authorization to basic Auth

Response header will contain the csrf token

Step 2: Send Data to BW

Add header x-csrf-token and set value returned by call in Step 1 (found in the response header)

Set body to message to post to BW (xml in this example)

Response back

Example JSON POST

 

Data Post example in CPI

The process below mirrors the process done previously in postman to post data to BW

 

Against the Integration flow set HTTP session

 

  1. Start Timer - Schedule set to Run Once
  2. Set Csrf token header

3. Make http call to get csrf token returned (note that in this example an on-premise BW is being called so virtual host/port have been set in cloud connector)

Make sure Headers are both passed to the call and returned

4. Handle Cookies - The initial csrf call returns an header called 'set-cookie', unfortunately the call to post the data requires an header called 'cookie'.  The groovy script converts the format and name.  More details can be found in https://help.sap.com/docs/SUPPORT_CONTENT/sci/3361897820.html?locale=en-US

import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message;

def Message processData(Message message) {

    def headers = message.getHeaders();

    def cookies = headers.get("set-cookie");

    message.setHeader("cookie", String.join("; ", cookies));

return message;

}        

5. Set content type and payload of data post

6. HTTP call to post data to BW

entry.title: SAP CI Just Started Talking to AI : Introducing the new AI Adapter for SAP Integration Suite
entry.content:
Ever wished your iFlow could talk to ChatGPT?
Now it can! With SAP’s new AI Adapter, your integrations can tap into the power of Large Language Models like OpenAI's GPT, making your processes smarter and more self-sufficient.

SAP has introduced a game-changing capability in its Integration Suite—the AI Adapter. Whether you're connecting to SAP AI Core via the GenAI Hub or tapping into OpenAI through REST APIs, this adapter allows your integration flows to think, respond, and act using the power of generative AI.

With the AI Adapter, integration is no longer just about connectivity—it’s about cognitive capability. You’re not simply passing data; you’re enabling your iFlows to understand, reason, and generate intelligent output in real-time.

It unlocks a new era of integration where:
  • Decisions are dynamic
  • Responses are contextual
  • Workflows are augmented with AI-driven intelligence

Your iFlow is no longer silent. It can now ask, interpret, and respond—like a real assistant embedded within your process.

From streamlining operations to enriching business workflows with human-like intelligence, the AI Adapter is a leap toward next-gen, AI-powered integration landscapes.

Key Features of the AI Adapter in SAP Integration Suite

The AI Adapter extends the power of SAP Integration Suite by enabling seamless integration with generative AI providers. It comes in two flexible variants and supports a wide range of intelligent capabilities:

Two Powerful Variants
  • AICore-GenAIHub: Connects directly to SAP AI Core’s orchestration services to consume multiple GenAI models using a unified configuration and deployment setup.
  • Custom-OpenAI-REST: Connects to OpenAI’s public APIs, enabling integration with advanced LLMs (like ChatGPT) for tasks like text generation, classification, and more.
Secure Authentication Options
  • OAuth2 Client Credentials for the AICore-GenAIHub variant.
  • API Key Alias (Secure Parameter) support for the Custom-OpenAI-REST variant.
Unified API Design
  • The AICore-GenAIHub variant uses a harmonized API, allowing you to switch between different foundational models without changing client code.
Custom-OpenAI-REST Capabilities
  • Full access to OpenAI’s powerful endpoints including Chat Completions, Platform metadata, Rich AI-generated responses and more
Dual Configuration Modes
  • Basic Mode: Simplified setup for common use cases and supported endpoints.
  • Advanced Mode: Full control for experienced developers to call any API endpoint with custom headers, payloads, and processing logic.

There are countless possibilities when it comes to leveraging the AI Adapter in SAP Integration Suite—whether it’s intelligent document processing, language translation, content generation, or decision support. But in this blog, we’re focusing on a simple yet powerful scenario that highlights intelligent automation in action.

Scenario: Generative AI-Augmented Error Handling

In this walkthrough, we’ll use the Custom-OpenAI-REST variant of the AI Adapter to build an iFlow that:

  1. Detects a failed message in your integration flow

  2. Sends the error details to OpenAI’s GPT model via the AI Adapter

  3. Receives a context-aware resolution from the AI model

  4. Creates a Jira ticket automatically with the AI-suggested resolution

Note: This is a foundational PoC that showcases how the capability can support exception handling. I hope it serves as a starting point for building more advanced and tailored solutions on top of it.

Setting Up Your OpenAI Account and creation of API Key

To integrate OpenAI with SAP Integration Suite using the Custom-OpenAI-REST variant of the AI Adapter, you'll need an OpenAI account and an API key. Here's how to get started:

Create/Open Your OpenAI Account

  1. Go to https://platform.openai.com

  2. Click Sign up / Log in

3. Setup your account / Create Organization

4. Set a API key name and Project name

 

5. Copy and securely store the API key (Caution: This key is shown only once—make sure to save it)

You can check all the configurations by clicking on your profile at the Top right.

Activate Billing on Your OpenAI Account (Mandatory for API Access)

Having an OpenAI account and API key is not enough. You must have an active billing setup.  Earlier, OpenAI offered free trial credits ($5 to $18) to new accounts.
But as of 2024, trial credits are no longer guaranteed, especially for accounts from certain regions (like India).

So unless you’re explicitly granted trial usage, the default quota is $0 — and any API call will fail unless billing is enabled.

How to Set Up Billing for OpenAI API Access

  • Go to: https://platform.openai.com/account/billing/payment-methods

  • Click "Add payment method", and enter your debit/credit card details.

  • Once the card is added, you are automatically enrolled into a pay-as-you-go plan.

If your account has no active quota, you’ll see errors like:

Reason: Invoke api failed, urlPath:https://api.openai.com/v1/chat/completions status:429 response: Too Many Requests
errorEntity:{
"error": {
"message": "You exceeded your current quota, please check your plan and billing details. For more information on this error, read the docs: https://platform.openai.com/docs/guides/error-codes/api-errors.",
"type": "insufficient_quota",
"param": null,
"code": "insufficient_quota"
}
}

All set on OpenAI end, Now lets hop on to our very own SAP Cloud Integration.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

SAP Cloud Integration:

For this demonstration, I’ve created an iFlow that uses the Google Pub/Sub Adapter with intentionally incorrect KeyPair/Certificate, triggering a failure during message processing. This failure is caught by the Exception Subprocess, where we harness the power of the AI Adapter to analyze the error and fetch a resolution using AI.

The returned resolution is then added as an attachment to the MPL (Message Processing Log) for traceability. Additionally, based on an external parameter, we can optionally trigger the creation of a Jira ticket containing the AI-suggested fix.

This blog will cover only the Exception Sub Process, keeping the spotlight on error handling within integration flows.

AI Adapter : Use a Request-Reply and pick AI adapter of variant Custom-OpenAI-REST from the dropdown.

 

 

Connection Tab:

ParameterDescription
AddressSpecify the OpenAI Address.
Example: https://api.openai.com
API Key Alias

Specify the API Key alias. Create a Secure Parameter in the security artifact to store the API Key that we created in OpenAI Account. 

Caution: The value of API Key Alias must be a combination of
<Bearer > and {API Key provided by OpenAPI}.

Reuse ConnectionEnable to reuse the connection.
Connection Timeout (in
ms)		Specify the maximum waiting time (in milliseconds) for the connection to be established.
Response Timeout (in ms)Specify the maximum waiting time (in milliseconds) for a response message.

Processing Tab:

ParameterDescription
Configuration TypeSelect the required configuration type:
• Basic to use the dropdowns and parameter text fields
• Advanced to specify the relative URL
Category"Chat Completions" : The use case is about sending a prompt to the model and get the response
Entity"Chat Completion"
Operation"Create a model response for the given chat conversation"
Request Payload
Source		- "UI Configurable" provides user friendly fields to create the payload
automatically.
- "Exchange Body" allows you to specify required structure and
values
ModelYou can select the model which is available to use for your openAI account. Make a GET call to this endpoint https://api.openai.com/v1/models to know the available models for your account
Prompt

Using UI Configurable in this use case, this field gets visible where we need to enter the prompt that goes as a request to the AI model.

Prompt : Suggest a possible solutions for the error : "${property.CamelExceptionCaught}" in 200 words plain text format. Do not include any special characters, double quotes and line breaks.

Request HeadersEnter a list of custom headers, separated by a pipe (|), to be sent to the target system
Response HeadersEnter a list of headers, separated by a pipe (|), coming from the target system's response to be received in the message

JSON to XML Converter : AI model returns the response in JSON format, it contains various fields, but our focus is on the "content" field which has the result. Its easier to extract the field from a XML file rather than a JSON. Hence there is a usage of JSON to XML Converter.

Response from AI model:

 

Content Modifier : "Extract Resolution" is used to extract "content" field from the XML.

Groovy Script : LogAttachment We will log the resolution that we received from AI model as an attachment in the Message processing logs:

import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message;

def Message processData(Message message) 
{
    def body = message.getBody(String)
    def messageLog = messageLogFactory.getMessageLog(message);
    def resolution = message.getProperty("resolution") as String
    if(messageLog != null)
    {
    messageLog.addAttachmentAsString("Resolution", resolution, "text/plain");
    }
    return message;
}

Process Call : "Call Jira", this process call executes the Call Jira local integration process. This is an optional configuration based on the External Parameter "CreateJiraCard", this is execute only when its value is "YES".

Jira Integration configuration is NOT covered in this blog, Check out the below blog for details related to Jira Integration.

Jira Adapter for SAP Integration Suite 

Demo:

Misconfiguration in GooglePubSub Adapter:

Keystore : No keypair found for alias "googlekey123"

Deploying the flow: Lets see how AI helps us with the resolution here.

MPL logs:

Attachment "Resolution": Response from AI model can be seen in this attachment

Response from AI: 

One possible solution for the error "org.apache.camel.CamelException: No key pair found for Private Key Alias: googlekey123" is to ensure that the private key with the specified alias "googlekey123" is correctly added to the keystore or key repository being used by the application.

First, you should confirm that the private key with the alias "googlekey123" exists in the keystore or key repository. If it does not exist, you may need to generate a new key pair with the correct alias and add it to the keystore.

Next, verify that the keystore or key repository configuration in the application matches the location and password of the keystore where the private key is stored. Make sure that the application has the necessary permissions to access the keystore.

You may also need to restart the application to ensure that the changes in the keystore or key repository configuration take effect.

If the issue persists, double-check the spelling of the alias "googlekey123" and verify that it is being referenced correctly in the application code.

By following these steps, you should be able to resolve the error and successfully retrieve the private key with the alias "googlekey123" in your application.

The Integration also created a JIRA ticket as shown below:

Pretty cool, right? The AI instantly analyzed the error and answered with remarkably accurate resolution—all within seconds. No manual debugging, no digging through logs—just a smart, contextual answer delivered right when you need it.

This is where traditional error handling ends and intelligent integration begins.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Conclusion: From Automation to Intelligence—This Is Just the Start

With the AI Adapter, your iFlows are no longer static pipelines—they become intelligent systems that can analyze, respond, and act with precision. From generating real-time resolutions to automatically logging tickets in Jira, and even notifying teams via email or chat platforms like Microsoft Teams—the potential is endless.

It’s a a blueprint for building truly smart integration scenarios that adapt, learn, and evolve with your business needs.

We now stand at the edge of next-generation integration design, where AI is not a bolt-on, but a native capability within your flow logic.

The question is no longer what can you automate?
It’s how far can you let your integrations think for you?

The future of integration is here—and it’s intelligent!!

References: AI Adapter for SAP Integration Suite

Up next : Curious about how the GenAI Hub variant of SAP AI Core fits into enterprise scenarios? The next blog has you covered — with an exciting new use case!

Hope this helps!

Cheers,

Punith Oswal

entry.title: Why Event-Enabling MDG with SAP BTP Advanced Event Mesh is a Game Changer
entry.content:
Why Event-Enabling MDG with SAP BTP Advanced Event Mesh is a Game Changer 

Introduction 

It is rare today to see a large enterprise with a monolithic system landscape; enterprises today target best of class solutions to meet the requirements of their business users, suppliers and customers.  This ever-growing landscape of heterogenous solutions increases the burden placed on integration tooling to keep their records and transactions in sync.  Lack of a true enterprise mesh to connect these applications will lead:  

  • Missing or duplicate records 
  • Data silos 
  • Out of Sync Records 
  • A fragmented view of business 

All of this will create a disjointed view of the business. Master data management is a critical function for any enterprise and requires strong coordination between business stakeholders and the IT teams that own and manage the solutions for master data.   

In today’s rapidly evolving digital landscape, data is only as powerful as its timeliness and accuracy. For organizations relying on SAP Master Data Governance (MDG) to manage core business objects like Business Partners, Materials, and Cost Centers, the need for real-time data propagation across systems is more critical than ever. Traditional integration approaches often rely on batch jobs or synchronous APIs that are fragile, tightly coupled, and reactive. 

This is where event-enabling MDG—using SAP BTP Advanced Event Mesh (AEM) with the Event Enablement Add-On—changes the game. By embracing Event-Driven Architecture (EDA), organizations can deliver real-time, loosely coupled, and scalable master data integration across the entire business landscape.  

A study by Aberdeen research showed that 66% of organizations do not have an IT environment that is cutting edge and built to support their needs around master data integration.  What held these organizations back was:  

  • Data growing at a faster rate than they could manage and analyze it  
  • There was strong difficulty sharing and accessing data across business areas  
  • Lack of IT resources to support the growing integration needs around master data integration 

 

However, enterprises that operate in a best-in-class strategy for master data management and integration see across the board improvement in operating profit, total customer base, revenue and employee retention. 

 

Why Event-Enable MDG System? 

SAP MDG is the single source of truth for enterprise master data, but its ability to share validated changes quickly and reliably across consuming systems is key to maximizing its value. 

Challenges with traditional MDG integration: 

  • A complex spider of point-to-point synchronous integrations that require a high level of development effort for any update or change 
  • Data is out sync due to legacy methods of integration such as batch file transfer  
  • Rapidly growing system landscape new systems being onboarded all with their own methodologies for sending and receiving data  
  • Lack of a centralized view to find catalogs of master data events within the enterprise  

Event-enabling MDG solves this by: 

  • New systems can rapidly be onboarded to consume master data events without disrupting the existing integrations 
  • Organizations can easily create an event catalogue to find and filter master data events relevant to their system  
  • Point to point connections can be eliminated by adopting an event driven asynchronous architecture allowing for decoupling of all downstream systems 
  • Events can be filtered allowing downstream systems to be notified only of events they care about 
  • Updates are pushed in real time to all downstream systems when an object is created or modified  

Key Use Cases & Benefiting Systems 

Real-world scenarios where event-enabling MDG unlocks high business value 

  • Material Master Synchronization 
  • Updates to Material data in MDG can trigger: 
  • Automatic replication to production planning systems 
  • Real-time updates to supplier catalogs or inventory platforms 
  • Notifications to product lifecycle or quality teams 
  • Sync updated UPCs/EANs to all subscribing systems in real time to eliminate product returns resulting from inaccurate product data or goods not being sold at check-out due to missed scans  
  • Business Partner Integration 
  • When a Business Partner is created or updated in MDG, an event can trigger updates in: 
  • S/4HANA core and satellite systems 
  • Customer portals and CRMs (e.g., Salesforce) 
  • Identity & Access Management tools (e.g., Azure AD, Okta) 
  • Global trade systems or compliance platforms 
  • Sync updates to Business Partner information to all subscribing systems in real time to eliminate issues with wrong, outdated or missing sold to and ship to information causing delays in orders, extra shipping costs and low customer satisfaction  
  • Cost Center & Financial Master Data Distribution 
  • Replicate Cost Center changes to subscribing systems in real time such as third-party HR, External Talent Management, Manufacturing Execution Systems, Travel and Expense systems to keep accounting data current and accurate 
  • Ease the pain during mergers and acquisitions in distributing changes to chart of account information to all subscribing systems enabling consistent financial reporting 

 

 

Benefits of Using SAP Integration Suite, Advanced Event Mesh with Event Add-On for MDG Integration 

The Event Enablement Add-On for MDG simplifies the process of turning master data changes into standardized events that are automatically published to SAP BTP Advanced Event Mesh. 

Benefits: 

  • Automatic Event Generation 

The add-on captures and publishes master data changes as events without requiring custom coding. 

  • Seamless integration with AEM 

Events are routed through Advanced Event Mesh for real-time, reliable distribution across subscribing systems. 

  • Reduced Development Effort 

Accelerates event-driven master data integration projects by handling event creation and metadata management out of the box. 

  • Loosely Couple Architecture 

Consumers subscribe to relevant event topics without impacting MDG logic. 

  • Scalable & Resilient 

Built-in guaranteed delivery, replay, and fault tolerance via AEM. 

 

 

Extending Event-Driven Integration with SAP Integration Suite 

While SAP BTP Advanced Event Mesh excels at delivering real-time events from SAP MDG & MDI, some integration scenarios require additional processing—such as data transformation, enrichment, or bridging to legacy systems that cannot consume events directly. 

SAP Integration Suite provides the ideal complement through lightweight micro-integrations (iFlows) that can handle these needs efficiently. This combined approach ensures enterprises benefit from the agility and scalability of event-driven architectures, while still addressing practical system integration requirements. 

 

Conclusion 

Event-enabling SAP MDG with SAP BTP Advanced Event Mesh represents a significant leap toward real-time, intelligent master data distribution. It enables enterprises to respond faster, integrate smarter, and govern better, all while reducing integration maintenance costs. 

If you're looking to modernize how your organization distributes critical master data, it's time to move from point-to-point to event-driven. Let’s start the conversation!

entry.title: SAP CPI Dynamic Router with External Rule Set using Camel Simple Expressions
entry.content:
Intro

Routing in CPI can get messy. As more routing branches are added, maintaining them becomes a headache, especially when conditions get complex or frequently change.

 

Background / Problem

I've explored a few ways to reduce this pain.

One is convention-based processDirect routing, e.g. building endpoint dynamically from headers like: /PD_${header.mestyp}_${header.rcvprn}. It’s simple and router-free, but can’t handle complex routing conditions.

Another is using value mapping for routing, lookup a field to get the processDirect path. See link at [Ref 1] & [Ref 2]. But VM has serious limits:

  • Only supports single field matching
  • No clean way to do AND logic without messy field concatenation
  • Can’t return multiple matching rows
  • No support for rich conditions like contains, startsWith, greaterThan, etc.

If you try to simulate those rich conditions in VM, it gets hacky, need to embed pseudo-logic in values, then decode with Groovy. That’s fragile and hard to maintain.

You could build your own rule engine, but that becomes a long-term maintenance trap. You’ll keep adding custom operators, fixing your own rule evaluation engine, and it won’t be standard. I wouldn’t go that route.

 

Inspiration

While revisiting the Dynamic Router pattern from Gregor Hohpe’s EIP book and Apache Camel, I realized: CPI should be able to support dynamic, flexible routing, if the conditions are externalized and evaluated at runtime.

The core idea of a true Dynamic Router:

  • Rules are externally maintained
  • Easy to add/remove/update
  • Supports rich conditions (not just equals)
  • Still simple to implement

Camel is the backbone of CPI, so I turned to Camel’s Simple Expression language.

 

Research

After revisit a great blog [Ref 3] by Eng Swee, found out able to use evaluate() method to get value using Groovy, however, it doesn't return single true or false.

Until at [Ref 4] Camel SimpleBuilder JavaDoc, found the method: matches()

 

Discovery

With SimpleBuilder.matches(), I can evaluate conditions like below with headers/properties in Groovy to Boolean true/false. Please note that for matches() method, Both ("and", "or") is not working, have to use actual operator (&&, II). Need double equal sign. Below 2 examples:

${header.type} == 'SO' && ${header.class} == 'A'
${header.partNumber.startsWith('FG')}

This opened up new possibilities and a clean path: I can store rules as just two fields:

  • endpoint (processDirect path)
  • condition (simple expression)

Evaluate them in Groovy using matches(). If it returns true, route to that endpoint.

 

How it work: Dynamic Simple Expression matches()

You can build "Simple Expression Tester" to test simple expression from Postman.

Step 1: Build an iFlow like below. Allowed Header(s) must be *

 

Step 2: Add the script testSimpleExpression.groovy that do evaluate() and matches() on some Simple Expression:

import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message
import org.apache.camel.Exchange
import org.apache.camel.builder.SimpleBuilder

def Message processData(Message message) {
    def headers = message.getHeaders()
  
    Exchange ex = message.exchange

    def evaluateSimple = { simpleExpression ->
        SimpleBuilder.simple(simpleExpression).evaluate(ex, String)
    }

    def matchSimple = { simpleExpression ->
        SimpleBuilder.simple(simpleExpression).matches(ex)
    }

    def condition = evaluateSimple('${header.condition}')
    def result = matchSimple(condition)

    def output = "condition: " + condition + "\r\n" + "result: " + result
    message.setBody(output)

    return message
}

Step 3: Positive Test Run. Header class & type matched the condition, result = true

Step 4: Negative Test Run. Changed class from A to B, then result = false

Step 5: Tried with some other method like startsWith() still work. I not tried all possible method, however believe as long as the method work in Camel Simple Expression, will work in this iFlow too.

 

Dynamic Router with External Rule Set (Simple Expression)

After testing and a few iterations, this worked well. So now ready to build a mini rule engine that is simple, dynamic, and avoids all the earlier pain points.

Step 1: Below will be our rule set in JSON, telling the processDirect endpoint and condition. The name field is just as an identifier for the rule.

[
    {
        "name": "ReceiverA",
        "endpoint": "/PD_SO_A",
        "condition": "${header.type} == 'SO' && ${header.class} == 'A'"
    },
    {
        "name": "ReceiverB",
        "endpoint": "/PD_PO_B",
        "condition": "${header.type} == 'PO' && ${header.class} == 'B'"
    }
]

Step 2: Build below 'Dynamic Router' iflow. For demo purpose, the sender is HTTP adapter. In actual you may change to processDirect. Allowed Header(s) must be *

Step 3: That "getPDSimpleRule" script, for now you can just use content modifier set static JSON rule set to property "simpleRule". We going to change to Partner Directory later.

Step 4: Script "doDynamicRouting". This script loop each rule, if condition matched, set the endpoint in property, also do logging in custom headers for traceability.

import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message
import groovy.json.JsonSlurper
import org.apache.camel.Exchange
import org.apache.camel.builder.SimpleBuilder

def Message processData(Message message) {
    def messageLog = messageLogFactory.getMessageLog(message)
    def properties = message.getProperties()

    Exchange ex = message.exchange
    def matchSimple = { simpleExpression ->
        SimpleBuilder.simple(simpleExpression).matches(ex)
    }
    def simpleRule = message.getProperty("simpleRule")
    def simpleRuleJSON = new JsonSlurper().parseText(simpleRule)

    properties.put("endpoint", "/not_found_from_rule")

    for(rule in simpleRuleJSON){
        def name = rule.name ?: ""
        def endpoint = rule.endpoint ?: ""
        def condition = rule.condition ?: ""

        def result = matchSimple(condition)

        if(result == true){
            messageLog.addCustomHeaderProperty("name", name)
            messageLog.addCustomHeaderProperty("condition", condition)
            messageLog.addCustomHeaderProperty("endpoint", endpoint)

            properties.put("endpoint", endpoint)
            break
        }
    }

    return message
}
 
Step 5: For demo, build 2 different receivers with processDirect. Each with sender address: /PD_SO_A and /PD_PO_B.

 

Positive Test Run (Go to ReceiverA)


 

Positive Test Run (Go to ReceiverB)

 

Negative Test Run (When no rule matches)

 

Where To Store The Rule Set?

One possible way is to store Json rule set in Partner Directory. SAP CPI do have UI to upload JSON to Partner Directory. Below are steps to upload JSON to Partner Directory:

Step 1: At CPI Monitor, go to 'Partner Directory'

Step 2: Click '+' to add:

Step 3: Maintain like below, browse to JSON rule set file, then 'Create'.

Step 4: After maintain, you should see like below:

Step 5: Replace the step 'getPDSimpleRule' with below script. This script get simpleRule JSON from Partner Directory.

import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message
import com.sap.it.api.pd.PartnerDirectoryService
import com.sap.it.api.ITApiFactory
import com.sap.it.api.pd.BinaryData

def Message processData(Message message) {
    def service = ITApiFactory.getApi(PartnerDirectoryService.class, null);
    if(service == null){
        throw new IllegalStateException("Partner Directory Service not found");
    }

    def simpleRuleData = service.getParameter("SimpleRule", "DynamicRouter" , BinaryData.class)
    def simpleRule = new String(simpleRuleData.getData())

    message.setProperty("simpleRule", simpleRule)

    return message
}

Step 6: If future need to maintain the JSON rule set, come here, Edit..

then just Browse and upload updated JSON rule file. Filename doesn't matter, Partner Directory will auto rename.

 

Closing Summary

This approach doesn’t aim to replace complex rule engines, but for many real-world routing needs, it strikes the right balance: flexible, simple, and maintainable. If you’ve struggled with hardcoded routers or limited value mappings in CPI, this might be a cleaner path forward.

What do you think about this approach?

If you’ve tackled similar routing challenges in CPI, I’d be curious how you approached it. Feel free to share your thoughts, improvements, or alternative ideas.

Disclaimer: This is a pattern I sparked from EIP pattern(Dynamic Router) and made workable in CPI, but it hasn’t been used in real production environments yet. Use it at your own discretion.

 

References:

[Ref 1] IDOC Dispatching - Use case for the ProcessDirect Adapter from @ArielBravo

[Ref 2] SAP Cloud Integration IDoc Receiver Handler from @aayushaggarwal

[Ref 3] Using Camel's Simple in CPI Groovy scripts from @engswee

[Ref 4] Class SimpleBuilder JavaDoc from Apache Camel

[Ref 5] EIPinCPI - Dynamic Router & EIPinCPI - Message Dispatcher  from @bhalchandraswcg

[Ref 6] Get to know Camel’s Simple expression language in SAP Cloud Integration from @MortenWittrock

[Ref 7] DynamicRouter EIP from Enterprise Integration Patterns (https://www.enterpriseintegrationpatterns.com/)

entry.title: Optimized IDoc Routing in SAP CI with Value Mapping and Groovy-Based Receiver Determination
entry.content:
Target Audience

This blog is primarily intended for the SAP Integration community seeking a strategy for routing outbound IDoc flows from SAP ECC or S/4HANA systems—particularly for those migrating from SAP PI/PO to SAP Cloud Integration (Formerly known as SAP Cloud Platform Integration or SAP CPI) and exploring effective alternatives to implement the same.

Motivation

In traditional SAP PI/PO-based landscapes, routing outbound IDocs from SAP ECC or S/4HANA systems is straightforward. A single t-RFC destination and IDoc port are typically configured in the sender system to forward all IDocs to SAP PI. Within SAP PI, routing is managed efficiently using the Integration Directory and centralized runtime (AEX), enabling reuse of a single IDoc destination across multiple interfaces and message types (MATMAS, INVOIC, DEBMAS, etc).

However, when migrating to SAP Cloud Integration, this simplicity is disrupted. Cloud Integration does not provide an equivalent mechanism for managing IDoc traffic using a central gateway or common destination. Instead, each interface often requires its own unique endpoint, destination, and port, making the configuration effort redundant and makes IDoc Routing complex  and operationally challenging, as part of this blog I wanted to tackle these challenges and simplify this. (* I wont go into the specific challenges of the different approches and rather focus on the problems I am trying to solve in the current approach)

 

Solution Approach:

As described in the flow above, we will implement the design using two iFlows:

  • IF_SAP_to_Generic_IDOCRouting:
    This iFlow receives IDoc XML messages from various SAP systems. It is responsible for receiver determination and routes the message to the appropriate target iFlow based on routing logic.
    In SAP PI/PO terminology, this iFlow handles the Inbound Processing and Receiver Determination steps of the integration pipeline.

  • IF_SAP_to_<Receiver>_<Interface Description>:
    This iFlow is specific to the receiver system and handles transformation, mapping, and other receiver-specific processing.
    In SAP PI/PO terms, this iFlow corresponds to the Interface Determination and Outbound Processing steps of the integration pipeline.

IF_SAP_to_Generic_IDOCRouting

Step 1: Extract Details from EDI_DC40 of IDoc xml and create Exchange properties: 

The IDoc routing in this flow primarily relies on Value Mappings and Groovy scripts. In this step, the necessary inputs and variables are initialized—these are later used in Groovy script execution to extract routing details from the configured Value Mappings.

For example, consider a sender system Q10 (the quality environment of the x10 SAP system with client number 001) sending an INVOIC IDoc with an extension type ZINVOIC01. The properties are initialized as below.

                                    

The sentReceiverCount variable is initialized to zero and is later used during processing when the same IDoc meets conditions for multiple receivers, ensuring it is sent to each applicable receiver accordingly.

Step 2: Fetch Receiver List for the IDOC from the Value Mapping tables using Exchange properties:

For this we would need to maintain two value mappings

Value Mapping for Sender Partner Number to Sender Identifier Conversion:

As an example, I have maintained the details of SAP systems x10 and x20 across their Development, Quality, and Production environments. You would similarly maintain all relevant SAP systems and their corresponding identifiers in the Value Mapping used for IDoc routing. This mapping typically requires updates only when new SAP systems are added or existing systems are migrated (when SIDs change), which are relatively infrequent events.

Value Mapping for ReceiverList, Receiver Determination and Receiver Target IFlow URls:

The second Value Mapping is maintained for each unique combination of SAP sender system and IDoc type.
For example, to define receiver determination conditions for the IDOC: INVOIC.INVOIC01.ZINVOIC01 sent from the SAP system x10, you would create a corresponding Value Mapping entry as shown below.

The ValueMapping will have 3 Mapping with agency as x10.INVOIC.INVOIC01.ZINVOIC01 (sender Identifier.IDOC)

IDOCName to ReceiverList : This mapping holds a list of all receivers applicable for a specific IDoc.

ReceiverName to ReceiverCondition: This defines the receiver determination condition for each receiver. The conditions should be maintained using XPath expressions to evaluate the IDoc content dynamically.

ReceiverName to ReceiverIFlowAddress: This maps each receiver to the endpoint URL of its corresponding integration flow (IF_SAP_to_<Receiver>_<Interface Description>) , as described earlier in the solution approach.

Now that we've covered how the Value Mappings are maintained, let’s look at how the Groovy script fetches the appropriate values:

1. Fetch senderIdentifier
The senderIdentifier is retrieved using the exchange property senderPartnerNumber (set in step 1). This value is looked up from the first ValueMapping.
Example:
If a message is sent from system Q10 with sender partner number Q10_001, the senderIdentifier fetched from the Value Mapping would be x10.

2. Construct Agency Key
Using the senderIdentifier and other exchange properties (set in step 1), the agency key is constructed. This key will be used to retrieve routing information from the second ValueMapping.
Agency Format:
<senderIdentifier>.<messageType>.<IDocType>[.<extensionType>]
     senderIdentifier – from first Value Mapping
     messageType – from exchange property
     IDocType – from exchange property
     extensionType – from exchange property (optional)
Example:
For an INVOIC IDoc of type INVOIC01 with extension ZINVOIC01 sent from system x10, the agency would be: x10.INVOIC.INVOIC01.ZINVOIC01

3. Fetch Receiver List
Using the constructed agency key, the receiver list is retrieved from the second ValueMapping.
Example:
For the agency x10.INVOIC.INVOIC01.ZINVOIC01, the receiver list will be:
Receiver1, Receiver2, Receiver3
Value Mapping sample call:

valueMapApi.getMappedValue(
  'x10.INVOIC.INVOIC01.ZINVOIC01', 'IDOCName', 
  'INVOIC.INVOIC01.ZINVOIC01', 'x10.INVOIC.INVOIC01.ZINVOIC01', 
  'ReceiverList')

Step3: Execute Receiver Determination Conditions (Groovy Script) from Value Mapping

The Groovy script then iterates through the receiver list, fetching the corresponding receiver determination condition for each receiver and evaluating it against the IDoc content using XPath.

// Fetch condition from Value Mapping
currentReceiverCondition = valueMapApi.getMappedValue(
  'x10.INVOIC.INVOIC01.ZINVOIC01',
  'ReceiverName',
  'Receiver1',
  'x10.INVOIC.INVOIC01.ZINVOIC01',
  'ReceiverCondition'
)
// Evaluate condition
def expr = xpath.compile(currentReceiverCondition as String)
def result = expr.evaluate(doc, XPathConstants.BOOLEAN)

If the condition evaluates to true, the receiver is added to the exchange property determinedReceivers. A counter variable determinedReceiverCount is also maintained to track how many receivers matched successfully.

At the end of this step, three additional exchange properties will be available: determinedReceivers, determinedReceiverCount, and IDOCName (which holds the constructed agency key).

In the example discussed, lets consider if the conditions are satisfied for Receiver2 and Receiver3, then the determinedReceivers list will contain both, and the determinedReceiverCount will be set to 2.
The IDOCName property (i.e., the agency key: x10.INVOIC.INVOIC01.ZINVOIC01) is also stored to be reused in subsequent steps of the flow.

Step 4: Send Message to Receiver Specific flow for the  Determined Receivers 

In this step, a looping process call is executed, which repeatedly invokes a local integration process to send the message to each receiver identified in the previous step—one at a time.

The property sentReceiverCount is incremented after each message is successfully sent to a determined receiver. The loop continues until sentReceiverCount equals determinedReceiverCount, at which point the process terminates.

To send the message to a specific receiver, a Groovy script is used to retrieve the receiver name from the determinedReceivers list. Using this name, the script fetches the endpoint URL of the corresponding receiver-specific iFlow from the second ValueMapping.

Value Mapping sample call:

valueMapApi.getMappedValue(
  'x10.INVOIC.INVOIC01.ZINVOIC01', 
  'IDOCName', 
  'INVOIC.INVOIC01.ZINVOIC01', 
  'x10.INVOIC.INVOIC01.ZINVOIC01', 
  'ReceiverIFlowAddress'
)

The fetched endpoint URL is then assigned to the header property receiverProcessDirectURL, which is used by the ProcessDirect adapter to route the message to the appropriate receiver-specific iFlow. IF_SAP_to_<Receiver>_<Interface Description> which would handle  transformation, mapping, and other receiver-specific processing.

 

Advantages of the Proposed IDoc Routing Strategy in SAP Cloud Integration

 The strategy outlined in this blog offers a scalable, modular, and maintainable alternative that aligns closely with enterprise integration requirements. Below are the key advantages of this design:

1. Reusability of Integration Flows

Instead of creating a separate iFlow for each IDoc-to-receiver combination, this approach separates:
Generic routing logic (IF_SAP_to_Generic_IDOCRouting)
Receiver-specific logic(IF_SAP_to_<Receiver>_<Interface>)
Benefit: Reduces development effort and avoids duplication across iFlows, enabling a clean and modular architecture.

2. Centralized Routing with Value Mappings

Routing conditions and receiver lists are managed through Value Mapping artifacts.
Benefit: Updates to routing logic can be done without modifying or redeploying iFlows—just update the Value Mapping configuration.

3. Scalable Across Systems and IDoc Variants

Routing logic is built dynamically using:
- Sender system identifier
- Message type
- IDoc type
- (Optional) Extension type
Benefit: Supports complex multi-system, multi-IDoc scenarios without inflating the number of artifacts or flows.

4. Native Support for Multi-Receiver Scenarios

The use of Groovy logic and looping constructs enables routing to multiple receivers based on evaluated XPath conditions.
Benefit: Enables 1:n routing scenarios, ensuring the same IDoc can be routed to multiple receivers without message duplication logic.

5. Low Maintenance and High Adaptability

This architecture requires Value Mapping updates only when:
- New SAP systems are added
- Existing systems are migrated
- Additional receiver conditions are introduced
Benefit: Minimal maintenance effort over time; no need for frequent design or deployment changes.

6. Aligned with SAP PI/PO Routing Model

The flow structure mirrors familiar SAP PI/PO pipeline steps, such as:
- Receiver Determination
- Interface Determination
- Outbound Processing
Benefit: Simplifies migration for teams transitioning from SAP PI/PO to SAP CI, while preserving key routing concepts. Also there is a scope for automation where you could write a code to automate creation of Valuemapping. The existing  ports can be reused by updating the RFC destination pointing to the SAP CI 

This approach attempts to addresses the Technical limitations of SAP CI’s IDoc handling, and also supports sustainable growth and cleaner and maintainable integration landscapes.

Additional Considerations for Retry and Reprocessing

  1. Retry and error handling should be implemented within each receiver-specific flow to manage failures independently for every receiver.

  2. It is advisable to avoid broadcasting IDocs directly from SAP Cloud Integration, especially in high-volume scenarios like master data distribution across multiple systems. This is due to potential limitations in storing failed messages within the SAP Cloud Integration tenant. Additionally, in broadcast cases, the retry mechanism should support resending only to the receivers where failures occurred, not all recipients.

  3. Exceptions can be returned to the sender system (e.g., via SOAP fault) so that errors are reflected in the originating SAP system(Return Exception to Sender ). This enables visibility in transaction logs like WE02/WE05, helping to identify and reprocess failed IDocs more effectively.

  4. Batch jobs in the SAP backend responsible for reprocessing IDocs should be adjusted based on the new failure status codes introduces by this setup

 

Conclusion

This blog attempted to present a scalable, maintainable, modular and  operationally efficient strategy for receiver determination of outbound IDocs from SAP system by leveraging Groovy script and Value Mapping. Also by decoupling the routing and receiver-specific logic into two separate iFlows, the solution ensures better reusability, easier maintenance, and greater control over message processing.

entry.title: AI Adapter for SAP Integration Suite
entry.content:
The AI Adapter for SAP Integration Suite is a Generative AI driven capability available exclusively on SAP Integration Suite. For the first time in SAP CI, leverage SAP AI Core’s GenAI Hub features that allow you to achieve smarter integration solutions for your business.

AICore-GenAIHub variant allows you to connect to orchestration services in SAP AI Core. This service enables the use of various generative AI models with a unified code, configuration, and deployment.

The Custom-OpenAI-REST variant of the AI adapter works with the APIs of OpenAI that allows developers to access and integrate with artificial intelligence models into their applications, enabling tasks like text generation, image creation, and more.

AI Adapter Features

The AI Adapter has the following features:

  • AI Adapter has two variants available: AICore-GenAIHub and Custom-OpenAI-REST.
  • AI Adapter supports OAuth2 Client Credential (User Credentials) and API Key alias (Secure Parameter) authentication methods for the AICore-GenAIHub and Custom-OpenAI-REST variant respectively.
  • AICore-GenAIHub employs harmonized API to allow you to use different foundation models without changing the client code.
  • You can configure orchestration to enable consumption of multiple GenAI models within a single workflow.
  • Custom-OpenAI-REST allows you to access a range of features using APIs like Chat Completions, Platform and Responses.
  • Custom-OpenAI-REST supports Basic configuration type that provides a convenient processing capability for supported versions whereas Advanced enables proficient users to perform calls with greater control while connecting to any API endpoint. 

Example Scenario : Sentiment Analysis on Customer Feedback 

In this blog post, we will demo a scenario to get you started with a basic AI Adapter operation. We query LLM to perform sentiment analysis on user feedback.

 

The following prerequisites are handy while getting started with GenAI Hub

  • To get started with Gen AI Hub, see Getting Started with GenAIHub.
  • To consume GenAI models using Orchestration, see AI Core Orchestration Consumption.

Prepare User feedback using Content Modifier

One of the first tasks we do after creating a new integration flow is to prepare contrasting user feedback to be analyzed. As you can notice, one of them speaks highly of the blog (we assume this to be a product) and other feedback is quite the opposite.

Connect to GenAI Hub using the AI Adapter

The Connection tab contains connection and authentication parameters to connect to AICore-GenAIHub.

 

Parameter

Description

Address

Specify the GenAIHub address.

Example: https://api.ai.{tenant_name}.{datacenter}.ml.hana.ondemand.com.

OAuth2 Client Credentials

Specify the name of the OAuth2 Client Credentials security artifact.

Reuse Connection

Enable to reuse the connection.

Connection Timeout(in ms)

Specify the maximum waiting time (in milliseconds) for the connection to be established.

Response Timeout(in ms)

Specify the maximum waiting time (in milliseconds) for a response message.

Prompt an LLM using AI Adapter

  4. Select Back-end Type as Non-SAP System and click Next.

entry.title: New integration packages for the Pipeline for Cloud Integration
entry.content:
I would like to share with you an important change for the Pipeline for Cloud Integration that we did based on feedback we received from customers running the Pipeline. As a result, new integration packages for supporting the Pipeline for Cloud Integration has been recently shipped on the SAP Business Accelerator Hub. Those packages replace the so far provided package Process Integration Pipeline - Generic Integration Flows & Templates which will be deprecated soon.

To be more flexible in setting up your different pipelines, different sender-specific IDoc and XI inbound flows, and receiver-specific outbound flows if required, we decided to split up the Process Integration Pipeline - Generic Integration Flows & Templates into four packages. For the same reason, the script collection has been replaced by local scripts.

Customers like to run different pipelines, e.g., for distributing their critical and non-critical scenarios across different pipelines, or setting up different pipelines in a shared tenant environment. Also, it makes sense to define an own IDoc or XI inbound flow for each sender system to be able for instance to define a sender-specific user role or to stop incoming messages for a specific sender system. For those uses cases, so far you had to copy the package with the complete number of integration flows from the Discovery to the Design adding a suffix. This ensured that the copied packages were not cut off from future updates. However, downside was that this resulted in a large number of stale artifacts, so integration flows which were not used at all.

With the new package setup, we now better support those use cases without creating all those stale integration artifacts. The approach is still to copy a new package from the Discovery, but depending on the use case, you would only copy the integration flows which are required for the respective use case.

You can now find the generic integration flows and a set of templates for the scenario-specific integration flows and custom exits spread across the following integration packages:

  • Cloud Integration Pipeline - Generic Inbound: Contains the generic IDoc and XI inbound flows.
  • Cloud Integration Pipeline - Generic Pipelines: Contains the main generic pipeline steps.
  • Cloud Integration Pipeline - Generic Outbound: Contains the generic outbound processing flow.
  • Cloud Integration Pipeline - Templates: Contains all templates for the scenario-specific flows and custom extensions.

Note: As said, the so far provided integration package will be deprecated soon. All new feature increments will only be shipped with the new integration packages. So, If you have used the previously provided package, you need to switch to the new packages. To do so, proceed as follows:

  • Undeploy all generic flows from the soon to be deprecated package.
  • Configure and deploy the required generic flows provided by the new Cloud Integration Pipeline packages. You can either deploy all generic flows or just the ones that you need depending on which pipeline you use, see below.
  • If you have used scripts from the script collection in your scenario-specific flows, replace the scripts with local scripts. You find the local scripts in either the generic flows or the new templates. As long as you haven't replaced all scripts, recommendation is to still run the script collection. Once done, you can then also undeploy the script collection.

Note: In the newly shipped Cloud Integration packages, the name and IDs of the integration flows have version v2 added. It's important that the old integration flows and the new integration flows must not be deployed together because they compete on reading from the same JMS queues.

The templates package doesn't contain any artifact which needs to be deployed nor does it need to be transported to the production tenant. It only contains templates that you can copy to create your scenario-specific flows and custom flows. For this reason, we kept those integration flows in a separate package.

For setting up the integrated messaging runtime for asynchronous communication (recommended option for asynchronous communication), you need to deploy the following generic integration flows:

  • (Optionally, if you like to use a single entry point for IDoc messages) Pipeline v2 Generic Step01 - Inbound Processing for Idoc
  • (Optionally, if you like to use a single entry point for XI messages) Pipeline v2 Generic Step01 - Inbound Processing for XI
  • Pipeline v2 Generic Step02 - Integrated Messaging Runtime Async
  • Pipeline v2 Generic Step06 - Outbound Processing

For setting up the integrated messaging runtime for synchronous content-based-router scenarios, you need to deploy the following generic integration flows:

  • (Optionally) Pipeline v2 Generic Step01 - Inbound Processing for XI
  • Pipeline v2 Generic Step02 - Integrated Messaging Runtime Sync

For setting up the fully decoupled pipeline for asynchronous communication, you need to deploy the following integration flows:

  • (Optionally) Pipeline v2 Generic Step01 - Inbound Processing for Idoc
  • (Optionally) Pipeline v2 Generic Step01 - Inbound Processing for XI
  • Pipeline v2 Generic Step02 - Inbound Processing
  • Pipeline v2 Generic Step04 - Receiver Determination
  • Pipeline v2 Generic Step05 - Interface Determination
  • Pipeline v2 Generic Step06 - Outbound Processing

All integration flows within the new Cloud Integration packages have been copied from the old package. Besides this, some new features have been added which I will soon describe in a bit more detail in a separate blog post. You also find this information in the change logs of the packages. Upfront, here some of the new features that we have shipped with the new packages:

  • For IDoc inbound scenarios where you exchange IDoc bulk messages, you have the option to keep the bulk, i.e., not to split the bulk message into individual messages.
  • You can now call a custom exit integration flow for custom pre-processing without the need to alter the standard generic flows of the pipeline. This can be configured globally or scenario-specific. Potential use cases could be to implement additional external or internal logging capabilities or to stop certain messages from sending to the receiver systems based on some conditions, e.g. maintained in the Partner Directory.
  • A new template has been added that allows you to implement custom receiver and interface determination by maintaining exchange properties. A similar approach is applied in the SAP Process Orchestration to Cloud Integration migration tool when selecting the standard migration approach for the Recipient List and Content-Based-Router patterns.
  • A new template has been added for an option to implement custom receiver determination based on a message mapping and by maintaining exchange properties for the interface determination. A similar approach is applied in the SAP Process Orchestration to Cloud Integration migration tool when selecting the Pipeline migration approach.
  • For the Outbound Processing templates, an option to call custom post-processing has been added.
  • We fixed an issue in the duplication check caused by a wrong usage of the escalation end event for the IDoc and XI inbound processing flow.

We are currently updating the standard documentation, so stay tuned.

entry.title: SAP RISE - Six Integration Patterns You’ll Face
entry.content:
In one of my previous blogs Why SAP ISA-M Still Matters – A Strategic Foundation for Modern Integration I have given some insights in which projects & situations I am currently using ISA-M to define my Integration patterns.  What should be more strategic then RISE nowadays?  

 

🧭 The Integration Architect’s Dilemma in RISE Projects

It usually starts with excitement — “We’re moving to RISE!”. But as the Integration Architect, you feel a shift in the room once you ask:

“How will your business-critical integrations survive the move?”

“How will our Integration Patterns change in a Private Cloud Environment?”

“Do we have to an option to be part of this modernization?”

In too many RISE conversations, integration is not part of initial phases , but everything depends on it. Whether you’re facing direct system-to-system integrations, legacy SAP PO platforms, or the modernization path toward Integration Suite and AEM: you need clarity.

 

Let’s talk about the 6 most common integration scenarios I encounter in RISE projects — and let’s do a deep dive into one of them.

📌Context: What Makes RISE Integration Different?

ISA-M allows us to talk in Integration patterns — proven, repeatable ways to connect cloud, on-prem, and hybrid landscapes.

Draw your Integration landscape abstract as below and repeat the same for all Integration Domains and Integration Patterns, maybe Integration Styles. We focus on the common Process Integration patterns which often are.

🔍 Scenario 1: On-Premise to On-Premise (e.g., existing ECC system → S/4, within same on-prem datacenter)

💬 Comment:
This is often the existing baseline. When the customers still host their systems locally. No RISE adaption in this case

🔍 Scenario 2: Private Cloud to Private Cloud (e.g., S/4 to S/4 Integration, within same RISE datacenter)

 

🔧Technology in use:

  • SAP Integration Suite, Edge Cell on a Private Cloud hyperscaler, such as Azure or AWS 
  • VPN or direct peering within same hyperscaler
  • Azure VNet Peering, AWS VPC Peering, or similar as secure tunnel
  • *SAP Integration Suite, Edge Cell on On-Premise landscape ( e.g. on SUSE or Red Hat) is also a valid option

Differentiators

  • Usage of Application Interface Framework for S/4HANA Monitoring
  • Usage of transactions and APIM Management operations
  • Usage of SAP CALM for overall central Monitoring ( if applicable)

🔍 Scenario 3: Private Cloud to Public Cloud (RISE workload connects to SaaS like SuccessFactors)

💬 Comment:

For hybrid Integration SAP Integration Suite could be used as natural entry point

🔍 Scenario 4: Public Cloud to Public Cloud (e.g., SuccessFactors ↔ Ariba or Salesforce ↔ S/4 in RISE)

💬 Comment:
This is a modernization sweet spot. Cloud-native to cloud-native with no concrete RISE touchpoints.

🔍 Scenario 5: On-Premise to Public Cloud

💬 Comment:
This is often the existing baseline. When the customers still host their backend systems locally but use SaaS applications for certain LoBs. No RISE adaption in this case

🔍 Scenario 6: On-Premise to Private Cloud (e.g., ECC → RISE in Azure, hybrid operation)

💬 Comment:
This hybrid pattern is very common in staged RISE transitions. Customers keep some systems on-prem while moving others (“early adaptors) into RISE.

 

🔧Modernization Reality Check

Most customers do one of three things:

  1. Move PO Interfaces to SAP Integration Suite, Cloud Integration  and SAP Integration Suite, Edge Cell  
  2. Modernize to SAP Advanced Event Mesh
  3. Use more featreus of the SAP Integration Suite, such as API Managmenet

So here’s what I recommend to every architect:

  • Audit your interface and integration technologies before RISE.
  • Classify interfaces using along the patterns in this blog.
  • Decide per pattern: Keep, Modernize, or Sunset.
  • Actively design your new integration landscape — don’t wait for someone else to.

 

📞 Let’s Build Smarter RISE Integrations

I’ve worked on numerous RISE integration journeys and built a reference architecture library covering each scenario. If you want to see the diagrams, dig into patterns, or compare your setup — I’m happy to help.

Ping us on SAP Integration Modernization <integration.modernization@sap.com>
