entry.title: Invoking LLM from Cloud Integration Responsibly – Made Easy with Generative AI Hub in SAP AI Core
entry.content:
In this blog post, I’ll walk you through how to seamlessly invoke large language models (LLMs) from Cloud Integration using the Generative AI Hub and the Orchestration Workflow API in SAP AI Core. We’ll focus on building a GDPR-compliant automation flow that leverages data masking and pseudonymisation to ensure privacy while still delivering value from generative AI.

The scenario we'll explore simulates a real-world use case: when a Business Partner record is updated in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, a personalized email notification is generated by an LLM and automatically sent out via Cloud Integration.

Thanks to prebuilt orchestration capabilities of Generative AI Hub in SAP AI Core, such as templating, I/O filtering, and data masking, the process of generating compliant LLM responses can be achieved with just a single API call.

 

Before diving into the implementation steps, let’s take a closer look at the process flow behind this sample scenario.

Process Flow (Steps)

  1. Business Partner Update in SAP S/4HANA Cloud
    A user creates or edits a Business Partner record in SAP S/4HANA Cloud.
  2. Event Triggered and Message Sent to SAP AEM
    The system triggers an event and sends a message to SAP Advanced Event Mesh (AEM).
  3. Cloud Integration iFlow Subscribes and Starts Processing
    The CPI iFlow subscribes to the AEM queue and begins processing as soon as a new message is published.
  4. Retrieve Old Payload from CAP Application
    The iFlow queries the CAP application to retrieve the previous version (old payload) of the Business Partner record from SAP HANA Cloud.
  5. Call the Orchestration Workflow API of SAP AI Core for AI-Based Email Generation
    With both the old and new payloads in hand, the iFlow invokes the Generative AI Hub using the Orchestration Workflow API of SAP AI Core to generate a personalized email body in HTML format. Here, a predefined orchestration pipeline applies data masking, prompt templating, and foundation model invocation to generate a compliant, personalised email body – without exposing any sensitive data.
  6. Send Email to Business Partner
    The iFlow sends the generated email to the Business Partner’s email address via a standard mail adapter in Cloud Integration, completing the end-to-end notification process.

As part of this blog, I will not focus on connectivity between SAP S/4HANA Cloud and SAP Advanced Event Mesh (steps 1 and 2). For a live step-by-step demonstration of the setup, please review this video: 👉 SAP Tech Bytes: Configuring SAP S/4HANA Cloud and SAP Integration Suite, advanced event mesh

Configuring Orchestration Workflow in SAP AI Core

Orchestration in SAP AI Core is a managed service that enables unified access, control, and execution of generative AI models through standardized APIs, templating, and configurable AI workflow components.

In our scenario, we will utilize it to chain together prebuilt steps, such as data masking and foundation model invocation, to generate a personalized email body in HTML format via a single API call.

To access the Orchestration service in SAP AI Core, you need to set up Generative AI Hub in SAP AI Core and SAP AI Launchpad. Please refer to either of the following resources for setup instructions:

  • SAP Discovery Mission: Set Up SAP AI Core Generative AI Hub
  • SAP Developer Center Tutorial: Generative AI with SAP AI Core - Setup

Before moving to the next step, please ensure that your orchestration configuration is deployed and is in the RUNNING status.

Building the Orchestration Workflow

In this example, we will build the orchestration workflow for the event of Business Partner change.

Within SAP AI Launchpad, navigate to Generative AI Hub -> Orchestration and click Edit Workflow to select the workflow steps you require.

For our scenario, deselect the Input Translation and Output Translation steps, as they are not needed.

In the Templating step, we define prompts that guide LLM on how to perform its task.

We configure two types of messages for our scenario:

  • System Prompt
  • User Prompt

The system prompt defines the overall behavior, tone, and role of the LLM. It sets global instructions that remain consistent across requests, ensuring predictable formatting and response style.

For our use case, the system prompt will instruct the LLM to act as a multilingual assistant that compares old and new Business Partner profiles and generates a compliant email.

You are a multilingual assistant. Your task is to compare the old and new payloads of a Business Partner profile and generate a personalized, polite, and human-sounding email to inform the Business Partner about the changes made to their profile. If no changes are found, reply "NO_CHANGES".
Instructions:
- Detect all relevant changes (ignore changes in fields named change_time or change_date).
- Summarize the changes clearly and concisely.
- Keep it concise and clear.
- Format the response as HTML (do not use code blocks).
- Use paragraphs (<p>) for separate blocks of text.
- Use an unordered list (<ul>) with list items (<li>) to list the changes.
- Address the Business Partner by full name if available.
- End the email with the following closing, exactly as shown: Best regards,<br>SAP BTP Adoption & Consumption Center.
- Keep the tone friendly, clear, and professional.
- Do not generate the email subject line, only the body.

The user prompt provides the dynamic, task-specific input for each request. Here, we pass actual data: the old profile payload, new profile payload, and target language. These placeholders will be replaced at runtime to generate personalized content.

Write the email in the language: {{?language_name}}
Here is the OLD profile payload: {{?old_payload}}
Here is the NEW profile payload: {{?new_payload}}

 

In the Data Masking step, we can anonymize or pseudonymize personally identifiable information from the input for selected entities. For our scenario, we will select the Pseudonymization option. This will substitute personally identifiable information in selected categories with a MASKED_ENTITY_ID placeholder and allow us to unmask the LLM response before returning it to the Sender.

The Input Filtering step allows you to apply content safety filters to the incoming data before invoking the foundation model.

In the Model Configuration step, we can select the desired model (e.g., GPT-4.1) and configure relevant parameters such as temperature, token limits, etc.

Finally, the Output Filtering step enables content safety filtering on the LLM-generated response to ensure compliance and prevent undesired content.

Once the orchestration workflow is configured, you can inspect its JSON definition and download it locally. This definition will be used later when invoking the orchestration workflow via API from Cloud Integration.

Additionally, you can test the orchestration inference directly within SAP AI Launchpad by providing sample input variables. The testing tool allows you to view and trace the LLM response and fine-tune the workflow configuration as needed.

When inspecting the output payload, you can clearly trace the results of each orchestration step – such as Input Masking, Output Unmasking, Input Filtering, and Output Filtering.

To learn more about Orchestration in SAP AI Core, refer to the SAP Developer Center Tutorials: Generative AI with SAP AI Core - orchestration.

Configure SAP Cloud Integration Business Partner Notification iFlow

Now that we have our SAP S/4HANA Cloud, SAP Advanced Event Mesh, and the Orchestration Workflow in SAP AI Core configured, we can proceed with the Cloud Integration iFlow configuration.

This iFlow ensures that Business Partner changes trigger compliant AI-generated email notifications, while maintaining data consistency in HANA Cloud. It leverages SAP Advanced Event Mesh, CAP, and Generative AI Hub for an automated end-to-end process.

High-Level iFlow Overview

  • Triggered by AEM Queue when a new event is published.
  • Retrieves BP details from S/4HANA Cloud.
  • (If event is BP update) Fetches old BP payload from HANA Cloud (via CAP service).
  • Invokes the Orchestration Workflow API to compare old vs. new payloads and generate an HTML email content while ensuring that no sensitive information is passed to LLM.
  • Upserts updated BP details into SAP HANA Cloud via CAP service.
  • Sends an email to the Business Partner.

Step-by-Step Process Breakdown

  1. Event Trigger
    • The iFlow subscribes to the AEM queue and processes incoming events.
  2. Retrieve Business Partner Details
    • An OData request is sent to SAP S/4HANA Cloud to fetch the latest BP details.
    • Key parameters (e.g., BP ID, BP email) are extracted and saved into the properties for further processing.
  3. Map to CAP Format
    • BP details are transformed into the CAP service data model.
    • The new payload is stored in XML and JSON format for further use.
  4. Conditional Logic
    • BP creation → No old payload is retrieved.
    • BP update → Old payload is retrieved for comparison.
  5. Retrieve Old Payload from HANA Cloud (BP update only)
    • The iFlow calls the CAP service to fetch the previous BP record. Please refer to the GitHub repository businesspartner_srv for more information on the CAP service. In our scenario, the CAP service acts as an intermediary that retrieves old Business Partner data from SAP HANA Cloud, provides an OData service for data access, and enables the upsert of updated details.
  6. AI-Based Email Generation
    • A subprocess calls the Orchestration Workflow API via the AI adapter to create a personalized HTML email body in a GDPR-compliant way.
  7. Upsert BP Details in HANA Cloud
    • The updated BP details are upserted into SAP HANA Cloud via the CAP service.
  8. Send Email
    • The iFlow sends an email using the Mail Adapter.

You can find this iFlow as a ZIP archive here: AEM_GenAI_BPMailGenerator_blog.zip

For this blog, we’ll take a closer look at Step #6, where the AI Receiver Adapter is used to invoke the Orchestration Workflow API configured in the previous section.

1) In our case, the easiest way to prepare a payload for the AI Receiver Adapter is by using a small Groovy script.

import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message
import groovy.json.JsonOutput

Message processData(Message message) {
    def map = message.getProperties()

    def createBP = map.get("EventType").toString() == "sap.s4.beh.businesspartner.v1.BusinessPartner.Created.v1" ? true : false

    // Dynamic user template
    def userText = createBP
        ? "Write the email in the language: {{?language_name}}\nHere is the NEW profile payload: {{?new_payload}}"
        : "Write the email in the language: {{?language_name}}\nHere is the OLD profile payload: {{?old_payload}}\nHere is the NEW profile payload: {{?new_payload}}"

    def userTemplate = [
        role: "user",
        content: [
            [
                type : "text",
                text : userText
            ]
        ]
    ]

    def systemText = createBP
        ? """You are a multilingual assistant. Your task is to generate a warm, professional welcome email for a newly created Business Partner profile based on the provided NEW profile payload.

        Instructions:
        - Welcome the Business Partner.
        - Address the Business Partner by full name if available.
        - Mention that their profile has been successfully created.
        - Format the response as HTML (do not use code blocks).
        - Use paragraphs (<p>) for separate blocks of text.
        - Keep it concise and clear.
        - Keep the tone friendly, professional, and approachable.
        - End the email with the following closing, exactly as shown: Best regards,<br>SAP BTP Adoption & Consumption Center.
        - Do not generate the email subject line, only the body."""
        
        : """You are a multilingual assistant. Your task is to compare the old and new payloads of a Business Partner profile and generate a personalized, polite, and human-sounding email to inform the Business Partner about the changes made to their profile. If no changes are found, reply "NO_CHANGES".

        Instructions:
        - Detect all relevant changes (ignore changes in fields named change_time or change_date).
        - Summarize the changes clearly and concisely.
        - Keep it concise and clear.
        - Format the response as HTML (do not use code blocks).
        - Use paragraphs (<p>) for separate blocks of text.
        - Use an unordered list (<ul>) with list items (<li>) to list the changes.
        - Address the Business Partner by full name if available.
        - End the email with the following closing, exactly as shown: Best regards,<br>SAP BTP Adoption & Consumption Center.
        - Keep the tone friendly, clear, and professional.
        - Do not generate the email subject line, only the body."""

    def systemTemplate = [
        role: "system",
        content: [
            [
                type : "text",
                text : systemText
            ]
        ]
    ]
    
    def language = map.get("language")
    def newPayload = map.get("new_payload_json")
    
    def inputParams = [
        language_name: language,
        new_payload: newPayload instanceof String ? newPayload : JsonOutput.toJson(newPayload)
    ]
    
    if (!createBP) {
        def oldPayload = map.get("old_payload_json")
        inputParams.old_payload = oldPayload instanceof String ? oldPayload : JsonOutput.toJson(oldPayload)
    }


    // Build the JSON structure
    def payload = [
        orchestration_config: [
            module_configurations: [
                llm_module_config: [
                    model_name: "gpt-4.1",
                    model_params: [
                        frequency_penalty: 0,
                        presence_penalty: 0,
                        max_completion_tokens: 24576,
                        temperature: 1
                    ],
                    model_version: "2025-04-14"
                ],
                templating_module_config: [
                    template: [
                        userTemplate,
                        systemTemplate
                    ],
                    defaults: [:]
                ],
                filtering_module_config: [
                    input : [
                        filters: [
                            [
                                type: "azure_content_safety",
                                config: [
                                    Hate: 2,
                                    SelfHarm: 2,

}

This script constructs the payload expected by the Orchestration API of SAP AI Core.

Note that the settings within the module_configurations block match the configuration that you downloaded from SAP AI Launchpad.

2) To set up a Connection to our AI Core Orchestration deployment, we first need to configure a Security Material.
In your SAP BTP Cockpit and access the service key of the SAP AI Core (extended plan) service instance created earlier.

Create an OAuth2 Client Credentials Security Material with:

  • Token Service URL: url from the service key + “/oauth/token”
  • Client ID: clientid from the service key
  • Client Secret: clientsecret from the service key

On the Connection tab of the AI Receiver Adapter:

  • Set the Address to the AI_API_URL from the service key.
  • Reference the Security Material in the OAuth2 Client Credentials field.

On the Processing tab:

  • Set Request Payload Source to “Exchange Body”.
  • Provide the Orchestration Deployment ID and AI Resource Group from SAP AI Launchpad.

3) JSON output is converted into XML for further processing.

4) Content Modifier step is used to extract the email_body from the Orchestration API response via the XPath expression: /root/orchestration_result/choices/message/content

Testing the Scenario End-to-End

With all components configured, it’s time to put the setup to the test.

📽️ Watch Event-Driven Business Partner Email Notification Demo 

The video walks through the entire process – showing the change in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, the processing inside Cloud Integration, and the final email received by the Business Partner.

Conclusion

This scenario highlights how simple and seamless it is to invoke SAP AI Core from Cloud Integration to generate compliant, human-sounding content.

With just a small Groovy script to prepare the payload, CPI can call an SAP AI Core Orchestration Workflow directly via the AI Receiver Adapter – without complex custom coding or middleware. All compliance safeguards, such as data masking and filtering, are handled by the orchestration workflow, ensuring that no sensitive information is ever sent to the LLM.

The result is an automated, end-to-end process where a Business Partner update in SAP S/4HANA Cloud triggers an event, CPI processes it, SAP AI Core generates the compliant email body, and the recipient is informed – all with minimal configuration effort.

This pattern can be applied to other master data objects and backend systems, as well as to any scenario where Cloud Integration must securely generate AI-based content — making it a powerful blueprint for scaling compliant AI adoption across the enterprise.

entry.title: ☁️ Real-time Weather Display on SAP BTP with OpenWeatherMap API — Step-by-Step Fiori Application
entry.content:
🔍 Introduction


This article I will show you step by step how to display real-time weather data in a Fiori application using the OpenWeatherMap API on SAP BTP. The application will request city information from the user and display information such as current temperature, humidity, and wind speed in a table format.

Output:

 

🛠️ 1. Obtaining an OpenWeatherMap API Key


Go to https://openweathermap.org/api.
Sign up and then create a new API key from the API keys tab.
Alternatively, an example request would look like this:
https://api.openweathermap.org/data/2.5/forecast?lat=44.34&lon=10.99&appid=e21c9996e2801f22e2bd0f7d11d1b367

💡This API key: e21c9996e2801f22e2bd0f7d11d1b367 can be used for testing. If it doesn't work, you can create a free one.

When we send a request with the link, it returns a JSON list like this:

 

🧱 2. Creating a UI5 Project in SAP Business Application Studio


A. Start a new Fiori application
SAP Business Application Studio > “Create Project from Template”
Template: SAP Fiori Application
Data Source: “None”
Project Name: weather-app
B. Project folder structure:
weather-app/
├── webapp/
│ ├── controller/
│ │ └── View1.controller.js
│ ├── model/
│ │ └── cityData.json
│ ├── util/
│ │ └── formatter.js
│ ├── view/
│ │ └── View1.view.xml
│ └── index.html
└── manifest.json

 

🌍3. Defining City Data as JSON


webapp/model/cityData.json:

{
    "cities": [
    { "name": "İstanbul", "lat": 41.0082, "lon": 28.9784 },
    { "name": "Ankara", "lat": 39.9208, "lon": 32.8541 },
    { "name": "İzmir", "lat": 38.4192, "lon": 27.1287 },
    { "name": "Bursa", "lat": 40.195, "lon": 29.06 },
    { "name": "Antalya", "lat": 36.8969, "lon": 30.7133 },
    { "name": "Trabzon", "lat": 41.0014, "lon": 39.7178 },
    { "name": "Gaziantep", "lat": 37.0662, "lon": 37.3833 },
    { "name": "Samsun", "lat": 41.2867, "lon": 36.33 },
    { "name": "Kayseri", "lat": 38.7348, "lon": 35.4676 },
    { "name": "Eskişehir", "lat": 39.7667, "lon": 30.5256 }
  ]
}

 

🎯4. View1.view.xml — UI Development

 

<mvc:View
  controllerName="weatherapp.controller.View1"
  xmlns:mvc="sap.ui.core.mvc"
  xmlns:core="sap.ui.core"
  xmlns="sap.m"
  displayBlock="true">

  <VBox id="IDVBoxMain" class="sapUiMediumMargin sapUiResponsiveContentPadding" alignItems="Center">

    <!-- Şehir Seçimi -->
    <HBox id="IDHBoxCitySelect" class="sapUiSmallMarginBottom" alignItems="Center">
      <Label id="IDLabelCity" text="Şehir Seçin:" labelFor="IDComboCitySelect" class="sapUiSmallMarginEnd"/>
      <ComboBox id="IDComboCitySelect"
                items="{/cities}"
                selectionChange=".onCityChange"
                placeholder="Şehir seçin"
                width="220px"
                editable="true">
        <items>
          <core:Item id="IDComboItemCity" key="{lat},{lon}" text="{name}" />
        </items>
      </ComboBox>
    </HBox>

    <!-- Anlık Hava Durumu Tablosu -->
    <Table id="IDTableCurrentWeather"
           items="{weatherModel>/Forecast}"
           inset="false"
           width="100%"
           class="sapUiResponsiveTable"
           growing="true"
           growingScrollToLoad="true">

      <headerToolbar>
        <Toolbar id="IDToolbarWeather">
          <Title id="IDTitleWeather" text="📡 Hava Durumu Tahmini" level="H2"/>
        </Toolbar>
      </headerToolbar>

      <columns>
        <Column id="IDColDate"><Text id="IDColTextDate" text="📅 Tarih Saat"/></Column>
        <Column id="IDColTemp"><Text id="IDColTextTemp" text="🌡 Sıcaklık (°C)"/></Column>
        <Column id="IDColFeels"><Text id="IDColTextFeels" text="🤒 Hissedilen (°C)"/></Column>
        <Column id="IDColDesc"><Text id="IDColTextDesc" text="🌤 Hava Durumu"/></Column>
        <Column id="IDColHumidity"><Text id="IDColTextHumidity" text="💧 Nem (%)"/></Column>
        <Column id="IDColWind"><Text id="IDColTextWind" text="🌬 Rüzgar (m/s)"/></Column>
      </columns>

      <items>
        <ColumnListItem id="IDRowWeatherItem" type="Active">
          <cells>
            <Text id="IDCellDate" text="{weatherModel>dt_txt}" class="sapMTextStrong"/>
            <ObjectNumber id="IDCellTemp"
                          number="{path: 'weatherModel>temp', formatter: '.formatter.formatKelvinToCelsius'}"
                          unit="°C"
                          state="Success"/>
            <ObjectNumber id="IDCellFeels"
                          number="{path: 'weatherModel>feels_like', formatter: '.formatter.formatKelvinToCelsius'}"
                          unit="°C"
                          state="Warning"/>
            <Text id="IDCellDesc" text="{weatherModel>weather_desc}"/>
            <Text id="IDCellHumidity" text="{weatherModel>humidity}"/>
            <Text id="IDCellWind" text="{weatherModel>wind_speed}"/>
          </cells>
        </ColumnListItem>
      </items>
    </Table>

  </VBox>
</mvc:View>

 

🎮5. View1.controller.js — API Consumption

 

sap.ui.define([
  "sap/ui/core/mvc/Controller",
  "sap/ui/model/json/JSONModel",
  "weatherapp/util/formatter"
], function (Controller, JSONModel, formatter) {
  "use strict";

  return Controller.extend("weatherapp.controller.View1", {
    formatter: formatter,

    onInit: function () {
      const oCityModel = new JSONModel();
      oCityModel.loadData("model/cityData.json");
      this.getView().setModel(oCityModel);

      oCityModel.attachRequestCompleted(() => {
        const aCities = oCityModel.getData();
        if (aCities?.length > 0) {
          const firstCity = aCities[0];
          this.loadCurrentWeather(firstCity.lat, firstCity.lon);
        }
      });
    },

    onCityChange: function (oEvent) {
      const sKey = oEvent.getParameter("selectedItem").getKey();
      const [lat, lon] = sKey.split(",");
      this.loadCurrentWeather(lat, lon);
    },

    loadCurrentWeather: async function (lat, lon) {
      const apiKey = "e21c9996e2801f22e2bd0f7d11d1b367";
      const url = `https://api.openweathermap.org/data/2.5/weather?lat=${lat}&lon=${lon}&appid=${apiKey}&lang=tr`;

      try {
        const response = await fetch(url);
        const data = await response.json();

        const row = {
          dt_txt: new Date(data.dt * 1000).toLocaleString("tr-TR"),
          temp: data.main.temp,
          feels_like: data.main.feels_like,
          humidity: data.main.humidity,
          wind_speed: data.wind.speed,
          weather_desc: data.weather?.[0]?.description || ""
        };

        const oWeatherModel = new JSONModel({ Forecast: [row] });
        this.getView().setModel(oWeatherModel, "weatherModel");
      } catch (err) {
        console.error("Anlık hava durumu alınamadı:", err);
      }
    }
  });
});

 

📄6. formatter.js

 

sap.ui.define([], function () {
  "use strict";

  return {
    formatKelvinToCelsius: function (kelvin) {
      const k = parseFloat(kelvin);
      return isNaN(k) ? "N/A" : (k - 273.15).toFixed(1);
    }
  };
});

Now, with this UI5-based Fiori application developed on SAP BTP, users can instantly view real-time weather data for their selected city. By developing projects like this using the OpenWeatherMap API, you can integrate external data sources into your system.

For more content, you can also find me on Medium (username: tekin.ilker24).

entry.title: Bridging EDI and SAP S/4HANA Cloud: Seamless EDI-to-SOAP Integration
entry.content:
In the fast-paced world of business today, it's crucial to connect traditional EDI systems with modern cloud ERP systems for streamlined operations. This blog takes a closer look at an integration fllow that handles inbound EDI messages, transforms them into SOAP format and facilitate effortless communication with SAP S/4HANA Cloud. Let's explore how this approach changes data formats and guarantees a reliable,standards-complaint integration between legacy and cloud systems.

Note:  For detailed steps on creating and exporting the required MIG and MAG files used in this integration, please refer to the blog: Creating MIGs and MAGs Using Integration Advisor i... - SAP Community.

Step-by-Step Guide: EDI to SOAP Inbound Integration Flow

Here’s a detailed look at the entire integration flow (iFlow) for processing EDI to SOAP inbound messages. This iFlow covers all the essential steps and components needed to receive, validate, transform, and route EDI messages into SOAP format, ensuring a smooth connection to the SAP S/4HANA Cloud system.

Step 1: Receive EDI Data via AS2

To initiate the integration, configure the AS2 adapter to receive inbound EDI messages. This configuration supports secure and reliable data transfer in B2B scenarios involving EDI communication.

Note: For detailed steps on setting up the AS2 adapter, refer to the blog: Step-by-Step Guide: Secure File Exchange with AS2 Adapter in SAP Cloud Integration – SAP Community

Step 2: Add Start Message

Add a Start Message event to initiate the integration flow when EDI data is received through AS2.

Step 3: Add EDI Splitter

Add an EDI Splitter for handling incoming EDI messages. It breaks them down into individual transactions, checks their structure for validity, and can also generate acknowledgments if necessary.

Important:All the XSD and mapping files mentioned in this flow( ASC-X12 XSD, preproc.xsl, and others)—are created and exported during the MIG and MAG setup process in SAP Integration Advisor.
For a step-by-step guide on generating and exporting these files, please refer to the blog: Creating MIGs and MAGs Using Integration Advisor i... - SAP Community.

  • Upload ASC-X12 XSD File
  1. To upload ASC-X12 XSD file, navigate to the X12 tab in the EDI Splitter configuration. You’ll find the file in the Source folder that was extracted during the MAG export.
  2. This file outlines the structure of the incoming EDI message, allowing the splitter to accurately parse and process the X12 message.

Step 4: Add Router

Now, let’s add a Router following the EDI Splitter. This step is crucial for separating EDI messages from acknowledgement messages, especially if you’ve enabled the generation of acknowledgements in the splitter.

Let's define two routing paths:

1. Acknowledgement Route: This route deals with acknowledgement messages independently.

In the Processing tab, you’ll see:

Expression Type Options:

  • XML: This is used when the message is formatted in XML.
  • NON_XML: This is for messages that aren’t in XML format, where routing is based on the message headers.

We opt for NON_XML since the acknowledgement message isn’t in XML, so the router checks the message headers instead of the XML content.

 Condition: ${header.EDI_ACKNOWLEDGEMENT} = 'true'

 

2. Default Route: Responsible for processing standard EDI messages.

No condition needed (processes all other messages)

Step 5: Integrate EDI to XML Converter

Now, let’s add an EDI to XML Converter to convert the EDI message into XML format.

  • Upload ASC-X12 XSD File

  1. Navigate to the X12 tab and upload the ASC-X12.xsd file from the Source folder that you got from the MAG export.
  2. The ASC-X12 XSD file defines the structure of the incoming EDI message, enabling the EDI to XML Converter to accurately interpret and transform the EDI data into XML format.

Step 6: Include XSLT Mapping (Pre-processing)

Next up, we’ll add XSLT Mapping to handle data preprocessing and transformation.

  • Upload preproc.xsl File
  1. Under the Processing tab, upload the preproc.xsl File from the Source folder extracted from the MAG export.
  2.  This step modifies the XML structure created from the EDI message, ensuring it aligns with the expected input format for message mapping.

Step 7: Add XML Validator (Post-processing)

Add an XML Validator to validate the pre-processed XML.

  • Upload X12_850_PurchaseOrder_MIG_RD.xsd File
  1. Navigate to the Validation tab and upload the X12_850_PurchaseOrder_MIG_RD.xsd file from the Source folder you extracted from the MAG export.
  2. This step makes sure that the transformed XML adheres to the expected schema before you proceed to message mapping, helping you identify any structural issues early on.

Step 8: Implement XSLT Mapping (Main Mapping)

Let’s add an XSLT Mapping to transform the validated EDI XML into the target SOAP message structure.

  • Upload Mapping_X12_850_PurchaseOrder_MIG_to_SOAP_SalesOrder_MIG.xsl File

  1. Under the Processing tab, you’ll need to upload the Mapping_X12_850_PurchaseOrder_MIG_to_SOAP_SalesOrder_MIG.xsl file from the root folder of the exported MAG zip file.
  2. This main mapping file, which was generated by SAP Integration Advisor (IA), is crucial for transforming the data into the right format for SAP S/4HANA Cloud.

Step 9: Apply XSLT Mapping (Post-processing)

Add an XSLT Mapping to adjust the mapped XML output to the final structure required by the target system.

  • Upload SOAP_SalesOrder_MIG_postproc.xsl File
  1. Head over to the Processing tab and upload the SOAP_SalesOrder_MIG_postproc.xsl file from the Target MIG folder.
  2. This ensures the transformed XML matches the exact format expected by the target system for successful processing.

Step 10: Add SOAP Receiver Adapter

Use the SOAP Receiver Adapter to connect to SAP S/4HANA and transmit the transformed XML payload over a SOAP-based web service. This adapter ensures that the data is encapsulated in a SOAP envelope and sent to the appropriate endpoint.

  • Address:Enter the SOAP service endpoint URL provided by your target system.

  • URL to WSDL:Click on Browse and upload the .wsdl file that corresponds to your target SOAP service. CPI will automatically fill in the Service, Endpoint, and Operation Name fields based on the WSDL information.
  • Authentication: Basic
  • Credential Name: Enter the Credential Name of the User Credentials you set up in Security Material.

This marks the end of the configuration for the EDI-to-SOAP inbound integration flow. With this iFlow in action, incoming EDI messages are handled efficiently and routed to the S/4HANA target system in the required SOAP format.

entry.title: CSV Download in RAP via SEGW
entry.content:
Introduction :

This blog walks you through the step-by-step approach to enable CSV downloads in a RAP application using SEGW, making data export simple and user‑friendly for end users.

Steps to Enable CSV Download in a RAP Application Using SEGW:

Step 1:  Create a Basic View – Define a basic CDS view based on the source table or view.

@AbapCatalog.viewEnhancementCategory: [#NONE]
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'Basic View for SO - CSV File'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
@ObjectModel.usageType:{
    serviceQuality: #X,
    sizeCategory: #S,
    dataClass: #MIXED
}
@VDM.viewType: #BASIC
define view entity z6na_cds_bv_so_csv as select from I_SalesOrder
{
    key SalesOrder,
    key _Item.SalesOrderItem,
        _Item.Material,
        _Item._MaterialText.MaterialName,
        @Semantics.quantity.unitOfMeasure: 'OrderQuantityUnit'
        _Item.OrderQuantity,
        _Item.OrderQuantityUnit
}

Step 2:  Create a Root View Entity – Build a root view entity on top of the basic view and apply the required metadata extension annotation.

@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'Root View Entity for SO- CSV'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
@Metadata.allowExtensions: true
define root view entity z6na_cds_rv_so_csv as select from z6na_cds_bv_so_csv
{
    key SalesOrder,
    key SalesOrderItem,
         Material,
         MaterialName,
         @Semantics.quantity.unitOfMeasure: 'OrderQuantityUnit'
         OrderQuantity,
         OrderQuantityUnit
}

 Step 3: Define a Metadata Extension and apply the required UI annotations.

@Metadata.layer: #CORE
annotate entity z6na_cds_rv_so_csv
  with  
{
@UI.lineItem: [{ position: 10,label: 'SalesOrder' }]
@UI.selectionField: [{ position: 10  }]
@Consumption.filter: { mandatory: true ,multipleSelections: true }
SalesOrder;
@UI.lineItem: [{ position: 20,label: 'SalesOrderItem' }]
@UI.selectionField: [{ position: 20  }]
SalesOrderItem;
@UI.lineItem: [{ position: 30,label: 'Material' }]
Material;
@UI.lineItem: [{ position: 40,label: 'MaterialName' }]
MaterialName;
@UI.lineItem: [{ position: 50,label: 'OrderQuantity' }]
OrderQuantity ;
}

Step 4: Implement a Global Class – Develop a global class to retrieve data from the source view and convert it into XSTRING format for CSV output.

  METHOD get_sales_order.

    DATA : lt_data    TYPE z6na_tt_so_af,
           lv_xstring TYPE xstring.

    SELECT * FROM z6na_cds_bv_so_csv
      INTO CORRESPONDING FIELDS OF TABLE _data
    WHERE salesorder = @i_vbeln.

    DATA(lv_csv) = |SalesOrder,SalesOrderItem,Material,MaterialName,OrderQuantity,OrderQuantityUnit{ cl_abap_char_utilities=>cr_lf }| &&
                    REDUCE string(
                    INIT lv_acc = ``
                    FOR <ls_out> IN lt_data
          NEXT lv_acc &&= |{ <ls_out>-salesorder },{ <ls_out>-salesorderitem },{ <ls_out>-material },{ <ls_out>-materialname },{ <ls_out>-orderquantity },{ <ls_out>-orderquantityunit }{ cl_abap_char_utilities=>cr_lf }|
 ).
    CALL FUNCTION 'SCMS_STRING_TO_XSTRING'
      EXPORTING
        text     = lv_csv
        mimetype = 'text/csv'
*       ENCODING =
      IMPORTING
        buffer   = lv_xstring
      EXCEPTIONS
        failed   = 1
        OTHERS   = 2.
    IF sy-subrc <> 0.
* Implement suitable error handling here
    ENDIF.

    r_form_content = lv_xstring.

  ENDMETHOD.

Step 5: Set Up an OData Project in SEGW – Create an OData project in SEGW to provide the download option for the CSV file.

Redefine the GET_STREAM method and write the logic there.

  method /IWBEP/IF_MGW_APPL_SRV_RUNTIME~GET_STREAM.

    DATA(lv_salesorder) = VALUE char10( it_key_tab[ name = 'salesdoc' ]-value OPTIONAL ).
    DATA(lv_csv_content) = new z6na_cl_so_csv( )->get_sales_order(
                                                 i_vbeln = conv #( lv_salesorder ) ).

    set_header( is_header = VALUE #( name = 'Content-Disposition'
                                     value = |attachment; filename={ lv_salesorder }.csv| ) ).

    copy_data_to_ref(
      EXPORTING
        is_data = VALUE /IWFND/IF_MGW_CORE_RUNTIME=>ty_s_media_resource(
        mime_type = 'text/csv'
        value     = lv_csv_content
    )
      CHANGING
        cr_data = er_stream
    ).
  endmethod.

Step 6 : Add Attachment Link Fields – Include the attachment/download link fields in the basic view, root view, and metadata extension.

Here, we need to attach the service name which we created in SEGW.

In Basic view,

@AbapCatalog.viewEnhancementCategory: [#NONE]
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'Basic View for SO - CSV File'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
@ObjectModel.usageType:{
    serviceQuality: #X,
    sizeCategory: #S,
    dataClass: #MIXED
}
@VDM.viewType: #BASIC
define view entity z6na_cds_bv_so_csv as select from I_SalesOrder
{
    key SalesOrder,
    key _Item.SalesOrderItem,
        _Item.Material,
        _Item._MaterialText.MaterialName,
        @Semantics.quantity.unitOfMeasure: 'OrderQuantityUnit'
        _Item.OrderQuantity,
        _Item.OrderQuantityUnit,
        'PreviewFile' as ShowCSV,
        cast(concat('/sap/opu/odata/SAP/Z6NA_ODATA_CSV_SRV/e_salesdocSet(''', concat( lpad(SalesOrder, 10, '0'), ''')/$value') ) 
        as abap.sstring(1300)) as LinkToCSV
}

In Root View , add the preview and link field.

@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'Root View Entity for SO- CSV'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
@Metadata.allowExtensions: true
define root view entity z6na_cds_rv_so_csv as select from z6na_cds_bv_so_csv
{
    key SalesOrder,
    key SalesOrderItem,
         Material,
         MaterialName,
         @Semantics.quantity.unitOfMeasure: 'OrderQuantityUnit'
         OrderQuantity,
         OrderQuantityUnit,
         ShowCSV,
         LinkToCSV
}

In metadata extension , add the URL(LinkToCSV field) in the UI annotation.

@Metadata.layer: #CORE
annotate entity z6na_cds_rv_so_csv
  with  
{
@UI.lineItem: [{ position: 10,label: 'SalesOrder' }]
@UI.selectionField: [{ position: 10  }]
@Consumption.filter: { mandatory: true ,multipleSelections: true }
SalesOrder;
@UI.lineItem: [{ position: 20,label: 'SalesOrderItem' }]
@UI.selectionField: [{ position: 20  }]
SalesOrderItem;
@UI.lineItem: [{ position: 30,label: 'Material' }]
Material;
@UI.lineItem: [{ position: 40,label: 'MaterialName' }]
MaterialName;
@UI.lineItem: [{ position: 50,label: 'OrderQuantity' }]
OrderQuantity ;
@UI.lineItem: [{ position: 60,label: 'CSV' },{ type:#WITH_URL ,url: 'LinkToCSV' }]
ShowCSV;
}

Step 7: Expose the Service – Create a service definition and service binding to make the functionality available for consumption.

@EndUserText.label: 'Service Definition for SO - CSV'
define service Z6na_cds_sd_so_csv {
  expose z6na_cds_rv_so_csv;
}

Step 8: Preview the application.

Conclusion: 

By following these steps, we successfully enabled CSV file download in a RAP application using SEGW. This approach not only simplifies data export for end users but also demonstrates how RAP and SEGW can work together to deliver practical business functionality.

Enabling this parameter will make the standard interfaces to invoke the Multiple Company integration logic. The interfaces will call the multiple company value mapping to fetch to identify the relevant SAP FSM company id and account id to which the business data to be replicated. This logic is identified in the “Fetch FSM Company” in each interface. Once the FSM company and account id’s are fetched, they are appended to the same incoming message as <FSMAccountID>|<FSMCompanyID> shown below.

Also, the data will be grouped for each FSM account ID and company ID pair for processing into FSM. Each grouped xml message will have the MultiCompanyGroup attribute with corresponding accountId|companyId value. For reference:

If no company Id is found from value mapping for the incoming data, then the account and company IDs are maintained as “NA|NA” and the respective data will be filtered out for replication into FSM. Such data will not be replicated to any SAP FSM company.

Special cases in Multiple FSM company data replication:

When working with multiple company integration between SAP S/4HANA and SAP Field Service Management (FSM), there are a few special cases to be aware of:

  1. No Matching FSM Company ID: If no FSM Company ID is found in the multiple company value mapping, the related data is filtered out and not replicated to any FSM company.
  2. In the integration between SAP S/4HANA Public cloud to SAP FSM
    1. Contact Data Handling:
      • Contact data is stored in the SAP CPI Data Store named BPContacts.
      • A contact is replicated only if it is assigned to a Business Partner.
      • The FSM Company ID is determined from the associated Business Partner using the multiple company mapping rules in the S/4HANA configuration for the Business Partner object.
      • Contacts are loaded into FSM together with their relationship replication.
    2. Data Retention:
      • By default, contact data remains in the CPI Data Store for 30 days.
      • Retention can be extended up to 180 days by adjusting the DS-ExpirationPeriod parameter.
    3. Business Partner Address:
      • FSM Company identification for Business Partner Address data is derived by the parent Business Partner interface, based on the Business Partner object itself.

In the integration between SAP S/4HANA Private cloud and SAP FSM

  1. Employee Data:
    • Employees are replicated to all FSM companies configured in S/4HANA mapping.
    • Assignment to a Service Organization is done later using the Assign Service Employee interface.
  2. Deactivating Unassigned Employees:
    • Employees not linked to any Service Organization can be deactivated using the Delete Business Partner Employee interface, run on an ad-hoc basis.
  3. Contact Data:
    • Contacts are replicated to all FSM companies as inactive.
    • They are activated only when linked to a Business Partner in S/4HANA, together with the relationship replication.
    • Company identification for contacts is based on the associated Business Partner.
  4. Item Group Data:
    • Item groups are replicated to all FSM companies configured in the S/4HANA multiple company mapping.

4. The Service Orders can only to replicated to any one FSM company based on the Sales Area or based on any specific field or using custom logic rule type as defined in the multiple company mapping configuration in S/4HANA. Replicating a single Service Order to multiple FSM companies is not recommended due to conflicts in Service Call ID acknowledgment.

 

This completes the configuration required in the SAP Cloud Integration to enable the multiple company integration functionality. Further, I will share the details on implementing the custom logic functionality to fetch the FSM Company

Seamless Multi-Company Data Replication in SAP Field Service Management - Part 1

The SAP Field Service Management (FSM) landscape is built on two key components: the Account and the Company. While the Account acts as the highest organizational level, a Company represents a specific legal entity, department, or business unit. This structure allows customers to manage multiple companies within a single FSM system to align with their business units. However, this creates a common challenge—replicating data from SAP S/4HANA to multiple FSM Companies. Data replication rules often vary depending on factors like Sales Area, Plant, Company Code, or Purchasing Group.

The standard integration content previously had a limitation, allowing data to be sent to only one FSM company at a time from S/4HANA Public or Private Cloud systems. With the 2023 FPS03 release, this limitation has been addressed—enabling standard integration from S/4HANA to multiple FSM Companies.

In this blog series, I’ll explore this new multi-company integration capability for both from S/4HANA public and private cloud system perspective. I’ll also share edge cases where implementing custom logic can help determine the correct FSM Company based on incoming S/4HANA data.

entry.title: Seamless Multi-Company Data Replication in SAP Field Service Management – Part 3
entry.content:
Custom Logic in Pre exits and Error Handling in Multiple FSM Company Replication in SAP Cloud Integration

In this blog part, I’ll explain how to use custom exits within the multiple company fetch functionality of standard interfaces to determine the relevant FSM company. I’ll also highlight the enhanced error handling introduced in SAP Cloud Integration as part of the multiple company integration feature.

Blog Series links:

Part 1 - Multiple Company integration overview and preparing S/4HANA systems for Multi-Company Integration

Part 2 - Configurations in CPI and Special handling of Business objects in Multiple Company integration

Part 3 - Achieving Multiple Company integration through custom logic implementation and enhanced error logging

Sometimes, the standard rule types provided by SAP—such as Sales Area, Company Code, etc—may not fit your business requirements for identifying the FSM company. In such cases, you can implement your own custom logic to determine the FSM Company IDs and Account IDs for incoming data. This custom logic can be implemented in multiple ways, depending on your integration scenario and business needs.

.

Custom Logic Using Pre-Exits for Multiple Company in Standard Interfaces:

In the S/4HANA Public Cloud to SAP FSM integration, you can leverage a pre-exit to determine FSM company details dynamically.

To enable this:

  1. In the standard interface where you want to apply custom logic, set the parameter Enable Pre-Exit MultiCompany to true.
  2. Create a Process Direct interface to implement your custom logic for setting FSM Account IDs and Company IDs.
  3. Apply your business rules to assign one or multiple companies as required.

This approach gives you flexibility to map FSM companies based on your specific business criteria before the data is sent to FSM.

 

Sample custom interface with custom logic to identify the FSM company and account id for the business partner object.

In the Groovy step “Set FSM Company details”, I have logic to different FSM account and company based on country code and for the FLCU01 role code. The identified FSM account and company details are appended to the same Business Partner message as in below format.

Similarly, this logic can be extended to any extent as per your requirement.

<FSMMultiCompany>
  <FSMCompany>accountid1|companyidA</FSMCompany>
  <FSMCompany>accountid1|companyidB</FSMCompany>
  .
  .
</FSMMultiCompany>

Later in the XSLT step “XSLT Group by FSM Company”, the message is grouped per FSM account and company Id pair using xml attribute “MultiCompanyGroup” as accountid|companyid. This group of data per each FSM account and company pair is required for the further processing of the data into each FSM company by the standard interface. More detail on how to group the message is provided in the following link Multiple Company Pre-Exits.

Final payload which sent back to standard Replicate Business Partner interface is as below. The standard interface will take care of posting the BP data to each FMS company in sequential batches.

In scenario of S/4HANA Private Cloud to SAP FSM integration scenario, you can either use the similar approach of using the pre exits provided for the multiple company fetch in the standard interfaces as shown above OR you can set the rule type as “Custom” in the S/4HANA multiple company configuration for the business object and implement a BADI to identify the FSM company ID in S4HANA.

 

Custom Logic Using Custom rule type in Multiple Company config in S/4HANA:

The Custom Logic rule type is available only for integration between SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud and SAP Field Service Management (FSM).

This option allows you to determine the relevant FSM companies using your own code or logic instead of predefined rules. To use it:

  • Create an implementation for the BAdI CRMS4_FSM_RELV_COMP_DETERM.
  • Assign the Custom Logic rule type to the desired Replication Object, Attribute, and Attribute Value in the multiple company configuration.
  • Use the same combination as a filter in your BAdI implementation.
  • If Custom Logic is required for multiple replication objects, create a separate BAdI implementation for each.

Example: To configure custom logic for Sales Customers:

Step 1: Assign Custom Logic Rule Type

  • Replication Object: Business Partner (BP)
  • Replication Object Attribute: BP Role (02)
  • Replication Object Attribute Value: BP Customer – Sales (FLCU01)

Step 2: Create BAdI Implementation with Filters

  • Replication Object (REPL_OBJECT): Business Partner (BP)
  • Replication Object Attribute (OBJ_ATR): BP Role (02)
  • Replication Object Attribute Value (OBJ_ATR_VAL): BP Customer – Sales (FLCU01)

This approach gives you full flexibility to define custom company determination logic that fits your organization’s business rules, while keeping it aligned with the multiple company integration framework.

 

Enhanced Error Logging in Multi-Company integrations:

In multi-company integration scenarios, SAP Cloud Integration now provides enhanced error logging to simplify troubleshooting and root cause analysis.

When data errors occur during replication to SAP Field Service Management (FSM) companies, the system:

  • Creates attachments in the Message Processing Log (MPL) with detailed error information.
  • Records custom MPL headers indicating the FSM company for which the data failed to load.
  • Generates separate attachments for each FSM company, ensuring issue tracking is company-specific.

If an error is generic (not linked to a specific FSM company), it is still logged in a custom MPL header containing the company and account ID, along with relevant attachments.

Handling Missing Company Assignments

When no FSM company can be determined for an incoming replication object, the object is filtered out and not sent to any FSM company.

  • These filtered object IDs are recorded in a dedicated custom MPL header.
  • All attachment file names are suffixed with the corresponding FSM company ID.
  • If multiple companies are determined for one replication object, separate attachments are created for each.

 

Custom MPL Headers in Multi-Company Error Handling

Value

Purpose

FSMCompanyNotFoundForBusinessPartner

Logs BP ID filtered out due to no matching FSM company

FSMCompanyNotFoundForBusinessPartnerRelationWithContact

Logs BP & Contact IDs filtered out due to no matching FSM company

FSMCompanyNotFoundForProduct

Product ID

Logs Product ID filtered out due to no matching FSM company

FSMCompanyNotFoundForWarehouse

Logs Product, Plant & Storage Location filtered out

Logs Condition Record ID filtered out

Logs Service Order ID filtered out

Logs Contact ID & company ID for FSM load errors

This improved logging framework ensures that every failure—whether company-specific or generic—is captured with context, allowing for faster resolution in complex multi-company setups.
